    All engineers, surveyors, architects or other professionals who are employed by the city shall maintain insurance for damages and costs resulting from errors, omissions or negligence in their employment in a minimum amount of $250,000.00 for each event. The minimum amount of insurance coverage as required in this section may be increased by the city manager, in his sole discretion, for individual projects or matters based upon their size, cost and potential for damage or loss. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  16) 
Sec. 22-5. - Sexually oriented businesses. 
(a)  Violations enumerated. A person commits an offense if he operates or causes to be operated within 1,000 feet of a church, a public or private elementary or secondary school, or a district restricted to residential use by the comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city or a public park adjacent to residential areas: 
(1)  A business or enterprise that offers for a consideration physical contact in the form of wrestling or tumbling between persons of the opposite sex; 
(2)  A business or enterprise that offers for a consideration activities between male and female persons and/or persons of the same sex when one or more of the persons are nude or seminude; 
(3)  A business or enterprise which offers for a consideration nude human modeling; 
(4)  A business or enterprise which displays for sale a book, magazine, newspaper, picture, photograph, drawing or other printed or pictorial material which explicitly depicts: 
a.  Human genitals in a state of sexual arousal; 
b.  Acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, or deviate sexual intercourse; 
c.  Fondling or other erotic touching of genitals, buttocks, or female breasts; or 
(5)  A business or enterprise which exhibits, displays, distributes or sells films, videotapes or other media which depicts: 
a.  Contact between any part of the genitals of one person and the genitals, mouth or anus of another person; 
b.  Contact between a person's mouth, anus or genitals and the mouth, anus or genitals of an animal or fowl; 
c.  Manipulation of a person's genitals; 
d.  Defecation; or 
e.  Urination. 
(b)  Exceptions. It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (a)(3) of this section that the business or organization is: 
(1)  A proprietary school licensed by the state; 
(2)  A college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or 
(3)  A private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college or university supported entirely or partly by taxation. 
(c)  Measurements of distance. For purposes of this section, distances shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest portion of the building used as a business or enterprise described in subsections (a)(1), (a)(2), (a)(3), (a)(4), or (a)(5) of this section to the nearest property line of the premises of a church or public or private elementary or secondary school or to the nearest boundary of a district restricted to residential use by the comprehensive general zoning ordinance of the city or to public parks adjacent to residential areas. 
(d)  "Seminude" defined. In this section, "seminude" means a state of dress in which clothing covers no more than the genitals, pubic region, and areola of the female breast, as well as portions of the body covered by supporting straps or devices. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  17) 
State Law reference- Sexually oriented business, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 243. 
Secs. 22-6-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 22-26. - Contractors' board of appeals. 
(a)  Creation of contractor's board of appeals. There is hereby created a contractor's board of appeals consisting of five members and two alternate members, each to be appointed by the council for a two-year term, or until a successor is appointed. Three members of the board and one alternate member shall be selected in even numbered years and two members and one alternate member in odd numbered years. In the event of a vacancy, the council shall appoint a member to serve for the unexpired term. Alternate board members shall serve in the absence of regular members. The contractor's board of appeals shall consist of the same members and officers as the zoning board of adjustment. 
(b)  Authority. The contractor's board of appeals shall have the authority to work with contractors and hear cases relating to building, mechanical, electrical and plumbing code requirements by hearing and deciding on reasonable interpretations of the previsions of all prevailing codes contained within Chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Colleyville and the fire code contained in Chapter 46 of the Code of Ordinances. The contractor's board of appeals shall have the authority to make a correct determination of any appeal arising from actions of the administrative authority, determine the suitability of alternate materials and methods of construction, consider and decide on complaints or suggestions relating to any of the building trades regulated by the prevailing codes contained within Chapter 18 and Chapter 46 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Colleyville. The board may make recommendations to the city council on changes in or additions to the current policies and procedures of the city that relate to the building trades. 
(c)  Quorum and organization. Four members of the contractor's board of appeals shall constitute a quorum. In the event of the absence of the chairman and vice-chairman, the four members constituting the quorum shall elect for that meeting a member to preside as acting chairman and to assume all duties of the chairman. 
(d)  Meetings, hearings and rules of procedures. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for the conduct of its meetings. Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman or at such times as the board may determine. All meetings and hearings shall be open to the public and shall be conducted in accordance with the procedure set forth in these regulations and the rules of procedure adopted by the contractor's board of appeals. Such rules of procedure may be amended by the contractor's board of appeals membership. The minutes of the meetings shall be recorded, showing the vote of each member upon the question, and shall be made a matter of public record. The concurring vote of four members of the board shall be necessary to render a decision on any matter before the board. 
(e)  Appeal procedure. A person may submit a request for an appeal to the contractors' board of appeals by filing said request with the building official. Each request shall be accompanied by a non-refundable filing fee. The filing fee shall be established by separate ordinance by the city council. In addition to considering an appeal request of an applicant, the contractor's board of appeals shall be authorized to solicit testimony and advice from recognized professionals within the applicable building construction trades. No decision of the contractor's board of appeals shall in any way have an affect as to amend the prevailing codes and ordinances of the City of Colleyville. 
(f)  Fees. No action shall be taken on any application submitted to the contractor's board of appeals until all applicable fees have been paid in full. No refund of any application fee shall be made after the request has been advertised and scheduled for consideration by the board. 
(g)  Public hearing. No action to approve or deny any application shall be taken until the board has held a public hearing and received comment. 
(h)  Appeal to city council. The decision by the contractor's board of appeals shall be final, unless the applicant submits a written notice of appeal within ten days from the date of the action by the board. The enforcement official shall place the applicant's appeal request on the next available agenda for consideration by the city council. The city council shall have the authority to overrule any decision of the board which it feels is not in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1980, ch. 3,  6; Ord. No. O-05-1509,  11, 2-15-05) 
Cross reference- Appeals from building code,  18-29. 
State Law reference- Notice of meetings, V.T.C.A., Government Code  551.041 et seq. 
Sec. 22-27. - License and fee requirements for certain building contractor trades and professions. 
(a)  License requirements and fee schedules. 
(1)  Required. Any person, referred to in this section as "contractor," who desires to engage in the trades or professions listed in this section within the city shall be required to obtain a license issued by the city. 
(2)  Fee schedule. Specific fees may be found in the Code of Ordinances Part II, Chapter 2 section 2-26, fees and charges for city services. 
(b)  Examination requirements. Contractors whose profession or trade requires a passing grade on an examination to work at a certain skill level as required by this city's prevailing ordinances and codes must show proof of such successful completion to that end to the building inspection division of the city. 
(c)  Period of license validity. The license applied for as provided in this section shall be valid for a period of twelve months. 
(d)  Violations; suspension of license. 
(1)  Any contractor engaging the services of an unlicensed subcontractor shall be considered to be in violation of this section in the same manner as an unlicensed subcontractor. 
(2)  The license of any contractor who has been convicted of a misdemeanor directly related to the duties and responsibilities of the licensed occupation shall be immediately suspended and be subject to review by the contractors' board, which shall determine the length of suspension, which length shall not be less than ten days nor more than one year. 
(f)  Penalty for violation. Any contractor in violation of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine as provided for in section 1-6. Each citation awarded shall be considered a separate offense and treated accordingly. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  11; Ord. No. O-15-1969,  3, 9-15-15) 
State Law reference- Eligibility of persons with criminal backgrounds for certain occupations, professions and licenses, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6252-13c; suspension, revocation or denial of license to persons with criminal backgrounds, guidelines and application of law, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6252-13d. 
Sec. 22-28. - Contractors working in public right-of-way. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the term "public right-of-way" means any right-of-way, roadway, easement, or other property which is held or owned by the city for any public purpose, whether such property was acquired by the city by dedication, purchase, adverse possession or otherwise. 
(b)  Permit required. 
(1)  No person, other than a contractor for the city, shall alter, modify, remove, or damage any improvement or property located in a public right-of-way without first obtaining a permit for such work from the city. 
(2)  Each person desiring to do work in a public right-of-way shall submit an application for a permit to the director of public works of the city on a form approved by the director of public works. The applicant shall submit such additional information as shall be deemed necessary by the director of public works prior to the issuance of the permit. 
(3)  The applicant shall also submit to the city a nonrefundable fee of $50.00. 
(c)  Escrow deposit. 
(1)  Prior to the issuance of a permit under this section, upon request by the director of public works, the applicant shall deposit with the city, in cash, a sum equal to 20 percent of the value or cost, whichever is greater, of the work to be performed in the public right-of-way. The director of public works, in his sole discretion, shall determine the adequacy of the deposit. The determination of the director of public works shall be final. 
(2)  The city shall maintain the deposit in an account created for the purpose of holding deposits for persons working the public right-of-way and shall segregate such funds from other city funds. The city shall disburse the funds deposited by the applicant in accordance with the terms of this section. 
(3)  The director of public works may waive the requirement of an escrow deposit if the director of public works finds that: 
a.  The applicant is of sound financial condition and is capable of responding to damages in the event the proposed work within the public right-of-way is not completed; 
b.  The applicant has a reputation for completing all work it undertakes in a reasonably prompt manner; and 
c.  The applicant has committed sufficient resources for the completion of the work in the public right-of-way in a reasonably prompt manner. 
(d)  Disbursal of escrowed funds. 
(1)  Upon completion of the work in the public right-of-way and acceptance of such work by the city, the escrow deposit shall be returned to the permittee, without interest. 
(2)  If the permittee fails to complete the work within the public right-of-way in a reasonably prompt manner, the director of public works may notify the permittee of this failure, in writing, by depositing in the mail, certified, return receipt requested, a written notice addressed to the permittee at the address given upon such permittee's application for permit. If the permittee fails to undertake to complete the work within the public right-of-way in a reasonably prompt manner within ten days of depositing such written notice in the mail, then the city may complete such work, either by performing the work itself or contracting for such work to be completed, and the cost of the completion of such work shall be deducted from the escrow deposit prior to returning such deposit to the permittee. 
As used in this subsection, the term "reasonably prompt manner" means the completion of the work in a diligent manner, having due regard for the type and nature of the work, the effect of the nonperformance of the work upon the public, and the resources the permittee has available. The determination as to a reasonably prompt manner by the director of public works shall be final. 
(e)  Insurance. Prior to the issuance of a permit under this section, the applicant shall provide proof to the director of public works that the applicant maintains public liability, bodily injury and property damage insurance in amounts of not less than $300,000.00 per incident, $100,000.00 per person and $100,000.00 for property damage, and vehicle liability insurance in an amount of not less than $300,000.00 per incident, $100,000.00 per person and $100,000.00 for property damage, which will provide insurance coverage to the applicant during the time period the applicant is working in the public right-of-way. 
(f)  Warning devices. Prior to the issuance of a permit under this section, the applicant shall submit to the director of public works a proposed plan for the establishment of barricades, flashing lights and other warning devices to warn the public of the dangers associated with the contractor's work in the public right-of-way, including the existence of trenches or ditches, existence of machinery or men working, storage of materials and equipment and unstable or dangerous terrain. All barricades, signs, lights, warning devices and traffic control procedures shall be utilized in accordance with the requirements of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(g)  Revocation of permit. If the director of public works determines that the applicant for a permit under this section is not maintaining insurance in accordance with the provisions of this section or is not complying with his warning device plan or has otherwise violated any ordinances of the city or provisions of state law, the public works director may revoke the applicant's permit to work in the public right-of-way. 
(h)  Provisions cumulative. The provisions of this section and the permit required hereby are cumulative in nature and not in lieu of or in substitution for any other permit, provision, condition or limitation of this Code. 
(i)  Franchised public utilities and their contractors. 
(1)  Prior to commencing any excavating work within a public right-of-way, public utilities and their contractors will be required to first obtain a permit in accordance with the provisions of this section. However, public utilities and their contractors which operate within the city pursuant to a franchise granted by the city shall be exempted from the permitting fee, escrow deposits, bonding, inspection, insurance and penalty requirements of this section. 
(2)  The surfaces of any street, alley, highway, public way or public place disturbed by the franchised utility in building, constructing, renewing or maintaining its plant and system shall be restored within a reasonable time after the completion of the work to as good a condition as before the commencement of work, to the reasonable satisfaction of the city. The franchised utility shall be responsible for all repairs and maintenance costs incurred as a result of any defects, impairments or other substandard condition in the street, alley, highway, public way or public place caused by the construction, maintenance or restoration work of the franchised utility. No street, alley, highway, utility or public way or public place shall be encumbered for a longer period than shall be reasonably necessary to execute the work. The franchised utility shall install traffic control devices in accordance with lawful city or state standards when such activity requires the full or partial closure of any vehicular travel way. Barricades, signs, lights, warnings and traffic control procedures shall be utilized in accordance with the requirements of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. The requirements of V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code  756.021 et seq. shall be met, if applicable. 
(3)  If emergency repairs become necessary for the restoration of utility service or other repairs become necessary to correct a situation hazardous to the public safety by a public utility, its contractors or subcontractors, a permit shall be applied for during the next business day following such emergency repair. 
(Ord. No. O-91-811,  1, 5-7-91) 
Secs. 22-29-22-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COIN-OPERATED MACHINES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Coin-operated services, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8801 et seq.; local occupation tax on coin-operated machines, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8814. 

Sec. 22-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin-operated machine means and includes every machine or device of any kind or character which is operated by or with coins, metal slugs, tokens, or checks; "music coin-operated machines" and "skill or pleasure coin-operated machines," as those terms are hereinafter defined, shall be included in such term. 
    Music coin-operated machine means and includes every coin-operated machine, of any kind or character, which dispenses or vends or which is used or operated for dispensing or vending music and which is operated by or with coins or metal slugs, tokens or checks. The following are expressly included within such term: phonographs, pianos, gramophones, and all other coin-operated machines which dispense or vend music. 
    Operator means any person who exhibits, displays or permits to be exhibited or displayed, in a place of business other than his own, any coin-operated machine in this city. 
    Owner means any person owning any coin-operated machine in this city. 
    Service coin-operated machines means pay toilets, pay telephones, and all other machines or devices which dispense service only and not merchandise, music, skill, or pleasure. 
    Skill or pleasure coin-operated machines means every coin-operated machine, of any kind or character whatsoever, when such machines dispense or are used or are capable of being used or operated for amusement or pleasure or when such machines are operated for the purpose of dispensing or affording skill or pleasure, or for any other purpose other than the dispensing or vending of merchandise or music or service exclusively, as those terms are defined in this section. The following are expressly included within such term: marble machines, marble table machines, marble shooting machines, miniature racetrack machines, miniature football machines, miniature golf machines, miniature bowling machines, and all other coin-operated machines which dispense or afford skill or pleasure. Provided, that every machine or device of any kind or character which dispenses or vends merchandise, commodities, or confections or plays music in connection with or in addition to such games or dispensing of skill or pleasure shall be considered as skill or pleasure machines and taxed at the higher rate fixed for such machines. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(A)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8801. 
Sec. 22-52. - Annual occupation tax levied. 
    Every owner, except an owner holding an import license and holding coin-operated machines solely for resale, who exhibits, displays, or who permits to be exhibited or displayed in this city any coin-operated machine shall pay, and there is hereby levied on each coin-operated machine, except as are exempt herein, an annual occupation tax in the amount of one-quarter of the annual tax levied by the state. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(B)) 
State Law reference- Amount of state tax, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8802. 
Sec. 22-53. - Responsibility of owner. 
    Nothing in this article shall prevent the operator of such machines from paying the tax levied in section 22-52 for the account of the owner, but the payment of such tax by such operator or other person shall not relieve the owner from the responsibility of complying with all provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(C)) 
Sec. 22-54. - Exemptions. 
    Gas meters, pay telephones, pay toilets, food vending machines, confection vending machines, beverage vending machines, merchandise vending machines, and cigarette vending machines which are now subject to an occupation or gross receipts tax, stamp vending machines and "service coin-operated machines" as that term is defined in this article, are expressly exempt from the tax levied in this article, and the other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(D)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8803. 
Sec. 22-55. - Sealing of machines by city. 
    The city is hereby authorized to seal any machine on which the tax levied under this article has not been paid. The city is hereby authorized to charge a fee not exceeding $5.00 for the release of any machine sealed as provided in this section for nonpayment of tax. Whoever shall break the seal affixed in the name of the city or exhibit, display or remove from location any machine on which the seal has been broken shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(E)) 
State Law reference- Sealing of machines by city, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8815. 
Sec. 22-56. - Construction of article. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed or have the effect to license, permit, authorize, or legalize any machine, device, table, or coin-operated machine, the keeping, exhibition, operation, display or maintenance of which is now illegal or in violation of any article of the penal code of this state or the constitution of this state. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(F)) 
Sec. 22-57. - Proximity to schools of certain machines restricted. 
    No skill or pleasure coin-operated machine shall be permitted within 300 feet of any school building in this city. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(G)) 
State Law reference- Coin-operated amusement machines near church, school or hospital, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8814. 
Sec. 22-58. - Occupation tax receipts. 
(a)  The occupation tax levied in this article shall be paid to the city secretary, who shall issue an occupation tax receipt. Such occupation tax receipt shall be attached to the coin-operated machine mentioned in the receipt and shall bear the serial number of the particular machine. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, exhibit, or display any coin-operated machine in the city without having attached thereto an occupation tax receipt. No occupation tax receipt issued for a specific coin-operated machine shall be transferred to any other machine. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  13(H), (I)) 
Secs. 22-59-22-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOUSE MOVERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Moving of buildings,  18-33; temporary removal of cable television wire for building moving,  26-31. 
State Law reference- Motor carriers and regulation by railroad commission, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 911b. 

Sec. 22-81. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined as provided for in section 1-6. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(I)) 
Sec. 22-82. - Permit required. 
    No person shall move any structure or building within or through the limits of the city where such structure or building shall be moved in, through, or upon the streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds of the city without first having secured a permit from the city secretary authorizing the same; provided, that no such permit shall issue for the moving of a structure or building into the city for reconstruction therein unless the owner thereof or his agent first secures a building permit for such construction and complies with the requirements of chapter 18, article II, of this Code. 
Sec. 22-83. - Bond required. 
    Before a permit under this article is granted by the city secretary, the person applying therefor shall give a surety bond payable to the city in the sum of $1,000.00, executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the state, to be approved by the city secretary and city attorney, conditioning among other things that such person will save, indemnify and keep harmless the city against all liabilities, judgments, costs, and expenses which may in any way accrue against the city in consequence of the granting of such permit. Upon the expiration of the time named in the permit, or sooner if the use of the streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds is no longer necessary, the city manager shall clear them of all obstruction. Provided, further, that the city secretary may refuse to issue a removal permit in a case where such work will necessitate the removal or cutting of any wires belonging to a public utility company, or to the city, until such time as the person making application for such permit shall have made satisfactory arrangements with the person or persons owning or controlling such wires, either by written agreement or by depositing with such company a sufficient amount of money to cover the cost of such work, that is, cutting and replacing the wires so moved or cut to the satisfaction of the persons owning or controlling such wires. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(B)) 
Sec. 22-84. - Contents of permit. 
    A permit issued by the city secretary to a house mover shall state specifically all the conditions to be complied with in moving, shall designate the route to be taken and limit the time for removal, and in no case shall paved streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds be used for such purpose unless such streets or grounds are on a route designated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(C)) 
Sec. 22-85. - Moving to be continuous. 
    The removal of a building under a permit, when commenced, shall be continuous during all the hours of the day, and day by day, and at night if required by the chief of police, until completed, and shall be carried on with the least possible obstruction to the thoroughfares occupied. No building shall be allowed to remain overnight upon any street crossing or intersection, or in such position as to prevent easy access to any fire hydrant. Lights shall be kept in a conspicuous place at each end and in the center of such building on all sides during the night. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(D)) 
Sec. 22-86. - Denial of permit. 
    If the chief of police deems it unsafe or dangerous to the public to move any structure or building over public roads or grounds on account of the condition of such building or structure, no permit shall be issued for such moving. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(E)) 
Sec. 22-87. - Report to city upon completion of move; inspection of streets; repair of damage. 
    Every person receiving a permit from the city secretary to move a building shall, within one day after such building reaches its destination, report that fact to the city manager, who shall thereupon inspect the streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds over which such building has been moved and ascertain the condition thereof. If the removal of such building has caused any damage to the streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds, the house mover shall forthwith replace the same in good repair as they were before the permit was granted. Upon his failure to do so within ten days thereafter to the satisfaction of the city manager, the city manager shall cause the damage done to the streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds to be repaired and hold the sureties of the bonds given by such house mover responsible for the payment thereof. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(F)) 
Sec. 22-88. - Nighttime location of buildings to be reported. 
    Every house mover shall make a report to the chief of police or his assistants every night as to the exact location where the building is to stand on the streets for the night. Failure to report this shall be a misdemeanor, and the responsible persons shall be liable to a fine as provided in this article. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(G)) 
Sec. 22-89. - Revocation of permit. 
    All house movers shall proceed in a careful manner with the removal of a building over the public streets, alleys, avenues, or public grounds and shall not in any manner interfere with the private property of individuals. The chief of police shall have the power to revoke any permit whenever in his judgment any house mover is proceeding in a reckless and careless manner in the removal of a building. 
(Code 1980, ch. 4,  9(H)) 
Secs. 22-90-22-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WRECKERS AND WRECKER SERVICES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Tow truck registration, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6687-9b. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Drop rate means the fee charged for a nonconsent tow which is disengaged pursuant to the provisions of section 22-115 while the towed vehicle is still on the premises from which it is being removed. 
    Nonconsent tow means a tow conducted without the permission of, or not at the direction of, the legal or registered owner of the towed vehicle, or such owner's authorized representative, and which originates in the city. "Nonconsent tows" shall not include tows made at the direction of the police department. 
    Parking facility means any public or private property used, in whole or in part, for the restricted and/or paid parking of vehicles. Such term includes but is not limited to commercial parking lots, parking garages, and parking areas serving or adjacent to businesses, churches, schools, homes and apartment complexes. It also includes a restricted portion or portions of an otherwise unrestricted parking facility. 
    Parking facility owner means any operator or owner of a parking facility, including a lessee, employee or agent thereof. 
    Tow service log means a record slip, record ticket, invoice, book or other written article that contains the address of the pickup and delivery of the vehicle being towed, the name and telephone number of the person ordering the tow, and the license number and identification of the vehicle being towed. 
    Wrecker means a motor vehicle or mechanical device adapted or used to tow, winch, or otherwise move disabled motor vehicles. 
    Wrecker service operator means a person engaged in the business of using a wrecker to tow, winch, or otherwise move a motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(A), 7-21-92) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 22-112. - Applicability. 
    The prohibitions and requirements of this article shall apply to all accidents and disablements regardless of whether or not the final resting place of a vehicle is upon a street immediately after the accident or disablement. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(C), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-113. - Presence at accident scenes restricted. 
    No wrecker shall arrive at the scene of an accident within the city unless such wrecker has been called to the scene by the owner or operator of a vehicle or his authorized representative or by the police department. Each wrecker operator, when called by the owner or operator of a vehicle or his authorized representative, shall notify the police dispatcher before proceeding to the scene of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(B), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-114. - Disengaging of tows. 
    Any wrecker service operator shall cease the removal of a vehicle upon the request of the vehicle's operator and upon the payment of the charges incurred to that point, except in the case of police pulls or in cases in which the police officer in charge determines that public safety requires the removal of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(D), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-115. - Notice of vehicle removal. 
(a)  Prior to a wrecker operator removing a vehicle pursuant to Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-2, the operator shall give oral or written notice of the removal to the person directing the removal and to the dispatch services of the police department. 
(b)  Prior to a wrecker operator removing a vehicle pursuant to a repossession, the operator shall give oral or written notice of removal to dispatch services at the police department. 
(c)  Under this section, notice to dispatch services at the police department shall consist of: 
(1)  The license plate number, registration year, state of registration, vehicle identification number if known, color, make, model, and style of vehicle being removed; 
(2)  The reason for the removal of the vehicle; 
(3)  The name of the person authorizing the removal of the vehicle; 
(4)  The location of the vehicle prior to its removal; 
(5)  The address of the vehicle storage facility where the vehicle will be stored; and 
(6)  The name, telephone number and address of the wrecker service removing the vehicle. 
(d)  Under this section, notice to the person directing the removal of the vehicle shall consist of: 
(1)  A license plate number, registration year, state of registration, vehicle identification number if known, color, make, model, and style of vehicle being removed; 
(2)  The reason for the removal of the vehicle; 
(3)  The location of the vehicle prior to its removal; and 
(4)  The address of the vehicle storage facility where the vehicle will be stored. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(E), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-116. - Compliance with state standards. 
    Any wrecker service operator shall at all times comply with all rules pertaining to minimum insurance requirements and minimum safety standards for the operation of tow trucks adopted by the state railroad commission pursuant to Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6687-9b,  3. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(F), 7-21-92) 
Secs. 22-117-22-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NONCONSENT TOWS 

Sec. 22-131. - License-Required. 
    A person commits an offense if he does not have a valid nonconsent tow business license issued by the city and he allows a wrecker under his control to be used in a nonconsent tow. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(2), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-132. - Same-Fees. 
(a)  The annual fees applicable to this division shall be as follows: 
(1)  Nonconsent tow business license fee, $200.00. 
(2)  Inspection fee (per wrecker), $20.00. 
(3)  Driver's permit fee (per driver), $15.00. 
(b)  The nonconsent tow business license application fee shall be $200.00. 
(c)  The charge to replace a lost or destroyed license, permit or inspection certification under this division shall be $5.00. 
(d)  The charge to reissue a license or permit under this division before its expiration due to licensee's change of physical address shall be $5.00. 
(e)  The nonconsent tow business license renewal late fee shall be $25.00. 
(f)  The fees charged in this section are to cover the administrative costs of investigation and processing. No fee payments shall be refundable. 
(g)  The fee for an original license or permit under this division which is issued for a period of time shorter than the city's fiscal year shall be prorated. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(1), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-133. - Same-Display. 
    An owner or manager of a nonconsent tow business commits an offense if he fails to prominently display upon his premises a valid nonconsent tow business license. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(3), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-134. - Inspection certificate required. 
(a)  The operator of a wrecker engaged in a nonconsent tow commits an offense if he operates such wrecker without displaying thereon, as required in this division, a valid inspection certificate issued to such wrecker by the city. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he allows a wrecker under his control to engage in a nonconsent tow when such wrecker does not display, as required in this division, a valid inspection certificate issued by the city. 
(c)  An inspection certificate issued under this division shall be displayed upon and affixed to the inside of the upper left corner of the rear window of the wrecker so that it may be read from the outside of the wrecker. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(4), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-135. - Driver's permit required. 
(a)  The operator of a wrecker engaged in a nonconsent tow commits an offense if he operates such wrecker without having been issued and without then and there possessing a valid driver's permit. 
(b)  The operator of a wrecker engaging in a nonconsent tow commits an offense if he fails to display a valid driver's permit to any peace officer requesting to see it. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if he permits a wrecker operator under his control to engage in a nonconsent tow without such operator having been issued a valid driver's permit. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(5), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-136. - License application and requirements. 
(a)  A nonconsent tow business license shall be valid only for the physical location indicated on the license. 
(b)  A nonconsent tow business license shall not be transferable. 
(c)  A nonconsent tow business license shall expire at midnight on September 30 of the fiscal year for which it is issued. 
(d)  An inspection certificate shall expire at midnight on September 30 of the fiscal year for which it is issued. 
(e)  An application for a nonconsent tow business license shall be in writing and sworn to on a form prescribed by the chief of police, and shall include the following: 
(1)  The wrecker service's name, physical address, mailing address and telephone number; 
(2)  The name, date of birth and home address of the applicant if a sole proprietorship; 
(3)  The name, date of birth and home address of each partner if the applicant is a partnership; 
(4)  The name, date of birth and home address of each corporate officer, if the applicant is a corporation; 
(5)  The name, date of birth and home address of each owner of the wrecker service, and the percentage of ownership interest each holds in the business; 
(6)  The name, date of birth and home address of the operator/manager of the wrecker service if it is not operated/managed by one of the owners; 
(7)  A list of all felony convictions and misdemeanor convictions during the five years prior to the date of application for which the maximum punishment is confinement in jail or a fine exceeding $500.00, against the applicant, a partner, a principal or general manager or officer of the applicant; 
(8)  A list of all Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-3 hearings during the three years preceding the date of application that involved a vehicle towed by or authorized to be towed by the applicant, a partner, a principal or general manager or officer of the applicant, or any employee thereof. Such list shall include the court in which the hearing was conducted, the date of the hearing and the court's ruling. It shall not be necessary to list hearings which resulted from a tow authorized by a peace officer while acting in his official capacity; 
(9)  As to each wrecker the applicant intends to utilize for nonconsent tows: 
a.  Its make, model, size and model year; 
b.  Its vehicle identification number; 
c.  Its Texas license plate number; 
d.  Its Texas tow truck license plate number; and 
e.  A photocopy of its certificate of registration issued by the state railroad commission; 
(10)  A statement that all of applicant's wreckers utilized for nonconsent tows are currently and will remain in compliance with state tow truck requirements as specified in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6687-9b, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto by the state railroad commission; 
(11)  A statement that the applicant is currently and will remain in compliance with the requirements of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 911b, and any regulations adopted pursuant thereto by the state railroad commission; 
(12)  A statement that the applicant is currently and will remain in compliance with the requirements of this article; 
(13)  A statement that the applicant is currently and will remain in compliance with Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-2; 
(14)  A certification from the city's tax department that the applicant has no delinquent taxes due to the city at the time of the application; 
(15)  A certification from an underwriter that the applicant has in force, for each named wrecker, a policy or policies of insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to transact business in the state that conform to the minimum requirements adopted by the state railroad commission; and 
(16)  An itemized list of standard fees charged by the applicant, including but not limited to nonconsent tows and a drop rate. 
(f)  An application for a license under this division filed by a corporation shall be signed and sworn to by its president and secretary. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(6), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-137. - Investigation of license application. 
    Upon the filing of an original or renewal application for a nonconsent tow business license, the chief of police shall cause such application to be investigated and all wreckers designated therein to be inspected. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(7), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-138. - Issuance of license and inspection certificates. 
(a)  Within 45 days after the filing of an original application (or 15 days after the filing of a renewal application) for a nonconsent tow business license, and upon the payment of the license fee and inspection fees, the chief of police shall issue a license unless he determines that grounds exist for its denial. 
(b)  Upon the issuance of the nonconsent tow business license, the chief of police shall issue a certificate of inspection for each wrecker named in the application which passes inspection. 
(c)  Upon the issuance of a nonconsent tow business license, the chief of police shall deliver to the licensee a copy of this article. 
(d)  Upon the denial of a nonconsent tow business license, the chief of police shall send the applicant a written notice of denial by certified mail, return receipt requested. Such notice shall state the reason for denial and the applicant's right to appeal. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(8), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-139. - Licensee's change of address. 
    No later than 15 days prior to moving the physical address of a nonconsent tow business, a licensee shall apply to the chief of police for an amended license. Such application shall be accompanied by the fee specified in section 22-132(d). 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(9), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-140. - License renewal. 
(a)  A nonconsent tow business licensee may apply to the chief of police for a license renewal no earlier than September 1 of the year the license expires. 
(b)  The application for renewal of a license shall be in writing and shall state: 
(1)  All changes to information contained in the original license application; and 
(2)  That all other information contained in the original application is true and correct. 
(c)  The nonconsent tow business license renewal application shall be sworn to. 
(d)  If a licensee fails to renew the nonconsent tow business license before it expires, he may renew it upon payment of the annual license fee and a late fee of $25.00. If an application for renewal is not filed by the 31st day after the date the license expires, the license may not be renewed. To reinstate the license, the licensee must comply with the requirements for an original license. 
(e)  A licensee whose nonconsent tow business license will be under suspension on its expiration date may file a license renewal application not earlier than 30 days prior to nor later than the date of the last day of the suspension. A licensee who files within this deadline shall be allowed to renew the license without payment of a late fee. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(10), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-141. - Driver's permit-Application; restrictions. 
(a)  A wrecker driver's permit shall be valid only for tows conducted for the licensee named on the permit. 
(b)  A wrecker driver's permit shall not be transferable. 
(c)  A wrecker driver's permit shall expire at midnight on September 30 of the fiscal year for which it is issued. 
(d)  A wrecker driver's permit shall be valid only while the licensee named thereon has a current, unsuspended, unrevoked license. 
(e)  An application for a wrecker driver's permit shall be in writing and sworn to on a form prescribed by the chief of police, and shall include the following: 
(1)  Applicant's name, date of birth and home address; 
(2)  The name of the licensee by whom applicant is employed; 
(3)  Applicant's places of residence for the last five years; 
(4)  A full description of applicant including his height, weight, eye color, hair color, distinguishing body features or marks, and an impression of his fingerprints and his photograph, both taken by the police department; 
(5)  A description of the applicant's experience driving tow trucks; 
(6)  A list of all felony convictions and all misdemeanor convictions during the five years preceding the date of application which are punishable by confinement in jail or a fine of $500.00 or more; 
(7)  A list of all traffic and wrecker offenses for which the applicant was convicted for the two years preceding the date of the application; 
(8)  Applicant's Texas driver's license number; 
(9)  A list of all times applicant's driver's license has been the subject of a suspension hearing, and the outcome of such hearings; 
(10)  A statement that the applicant knows the requirements of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-2, and those of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6687-9b, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto; and 
(11)  A list of all Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-3 hearings during the three years preceding the date of the application that involved a vehicle towed by or authorized to be towed by the applicant. Such list shall include the court in which the hearing was conducted, the date of the hearing and the court's ruling. It shall not be necessary to list hearings which resulted from a tow authorized by a peace officer while acting in his official capacity. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(11), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-142. - Same-Investigation of application. 
    Upon the filing of an original or renewal application for a wrecker driver's permit, the chief of police shall cause such application to be investigated. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(12), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-143. - Same-Issuance. 
(a)  Within 15 days after the filing of an original or renewal application for a wrecker driver's permit, and upon the payment of the driver's permit fee, the chief of police shall issue a permit unless he determines that grounds exist for its denial. 
(b)  A wrecker driver's permit shall include a photograph, physical description and home address of the permittee, the name and address of the licensee for whom he works and an identification number issued to him by the chief of police. 
(c)  Upon the denial of a wrecker driver's permit, the chief of police shall send written notification of such denial to the applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested. Such notification shall state the reason for the denial and the applicant's right to appeal. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(13), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-144. - Same-Renewal. 
(a)  A permittee may apply to the chief of police for a wrecker driver's permit renewal no earlier than September 1 of the year it expires. 
(b)  The application for renewal of a wrecker driver's permit shall be in writing and shall state: 
(1)  All changes to information contained in the original driver's permit application; and 
(2)  That all other information contained in the original application is true and correct. 
(c)  The wrecker driver's permit renewal application shall be sworn to. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(14), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-145. - Grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of license. 
    The following shall be grounds for the chief of police to deny an original or renewal application for a nonconsent tow business license, or, after a hearing, to suspend or revoke a license, if the chief determines that the applicant or licensee, a partner of the applicant or licensee, a principal in the applicant's or licensee's business, or an employee of the applicant's or licensee's business: 
(1)  Has been finally convicted of a felony which relates directly to the duty or responsibility of towing vehicles or operating a vehicle storage facility; 
(2)  Has within the five years preceding the date of the most recent license application been finally convicted of a misdemeanor that is punishable by confinement or by a fine exceeding $500.00, and which relates directly to the duty or responsibility of towing vehicles or operating a vehicle storage facility; 
(3)  Has within the three years preceding the date of the most recent license application made or authorized the nonconsent tow of a vehicle without probable cause as determined by a magistrate; 
(4)  Has had within the three years preceding the date of the most recent license application a vehicle storage facility license or tow truck certificate of registration denied, revoked or suspended by the state railroad commission; or his nonconsent tow business license or driver's permit denied, revoked or suspended by the city; 
(5)  Failed to maintain the minimum insurance requirements as directed under this division; 
(6)  Charged a person a fee for a nonconsent tow which exceeded those filed by the applicant under this division, or which was not allowed under this division; 
(7)  Made a false statement on a nonconsent tow business license application; 
(8)  Received more than two convictions in a 12-month period for a violation of this article; 
(9)  Failed to comply with the recordkeeping provisions under this article, as set forth in section 22-150; or 
(10)  Failed to comply with the signage provisions under this article, as set forth in section 22-151. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(15), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-146. - Grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of driver's permit. 
    The following shall be grounds for the chief of police to deny an original or renewal application for a wrecker driver's permit, or, after a hearing, to suspend or revoke a permit if the chief determines that the applicant or permittee: 
(1)  Has been convicted of a felony which relates directly to the duty or responsibility of towing vehicles or operating a vehicle storage facility; 
(2)  Has within the five years preceding the date of the most recent permit application been finally convicted of a misdemeanor that is punishable by confinement or by a fine exceeding $500.00, and which relates directly to the duty or responsibility of towing vehicles or operating a vehicle storage facility; 
(3)  Has within the three years preceding the date of his most recent permit application made or authorized the nonconsent tow of a vehicle without probable cause as determined by a magistrate; 
(4)  Has had within the three years preceding the date of his most recent permit application a vehicle storage facility license or tow truck certificate of registration denied, revoked or suspended by the state railroad commission; or his nonconsent tow business license or driver's permit denied, revoked or suspended by the city; 
(5)  Made a false statement on a driver's permit application; 
(6)  Received convictions during the year prior to the date of the original application for more than two violations of this article, moving traffic violations, or a combination thereof; 
(7)  While a permittee, received more than two convictions in a one-year period for violation of this article, a moving traffic violation, or any combination thereof; or 
(8)  Failed to comply with the signage provisions under this division, as set forth in section 22-151. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(16), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-147. - Hearing on revocation of license or permit. 
    When it comes to the attention of the chief of police that grounds exist for the revocation of a license or permit issued under this division, he shall schedule a hearing, and the following procedures shall be observed: 
(1)  Notice of hearing. 
a.  Service. The chief of police shall issue a notice to a licensee or permittee of such hearing with service by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service. 
b.  Contents. A hearing notice shall be in writing and shall name the place, date and time of the hearing. The notice shall also set forth a summary of the charges. 
c.  Hearing date. A hearing shall be scheduled for a date no later than 15 days after the notice is issued. 
(2)  Hearings officer. The chief of police or his designee shall preside at the hearing as hearings officer. 
(3)  Findings. At the conclusion of a hearing, the hearings officer shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law without undue delay. The hearings officer shall further issue written orders appropriate to his findings. 
(4)  Order to revoke or suspend license or permit. If grounds exist for the revocation of a license or permit, the hearings officer may order such license or permit revoked or may order it suspended for a period not to exceed six months. 
(5)  Notice of decision. A copy of the findings, conclusions and order shall be delivered to the licensee or permittee. If the hearings officer suspends or revokes a license or permit, he shall further deliver to the licensee or permittee written notice of the right to appeal. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(17), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-148. - Denial, suspension or revocation of license or permit-Determining factors. 
(a)  In determining whether to deny, suspend, or revoke a license or driver's permit under this division, the chief of police shall consider: 
(1)  The seriousness of the violation; 
(2)  The history of previous violations; 
(3)  The sanction necessary to deter future violations; 
(4)  Efforts made to correct the violation; and 
(5)  In determining whether a criminal conviction directly relates to the duty or responsibility of towing or storing vehicles, the chief of police shall consider: 
a.  The nature and seriousness of the crime; 
b.  The relationship of the crime to the purposes for requiring a license or permit; 
c.  The extent to which a license or permit might offer an opportunity to engage in further criminal activity of the same type as that in which the person previously had been involved; 
d.  The relationship of the crime to the ability, capacity, or fitness required to perform the duties and discharge the responsibilities of the license or permit; and 
e.  In addition to the factors that may be considered above, the chief of police, in determining the present fitness of a person who has been convicted of a crime, shall consider the following evidence: 
1.  The extent and nature of the person's past criminal activity; 
2.  The age of the person at the time of the commission of the crime; 
3.  The amount of time that has elapsed since the person's last criminal activity; 
4.  The conduct and work activity of the person prior to and following the criminal activity; 
5.  Evidence of the person's rehabilitation or rehabilitative effort while incarcerated or following release; and 
6.  Other evidence of the person's present fitness, including letters of recommendation from prosecution, law enforcement, and correctional officers who prosecuted, arrested, or had custodial responsibility for the person; the sheriff and chief of police in the community where the person resides, and any other persons in contact with the convicted person. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to the extent possible to secure and provide to the chief of police the recommendations of prosecution, law enforcement, and correctional authorities. The applicant shall also furnish proof in such form as may be required by the chief of police that he has maintained a record of steady employment and has supported his dependents and has otherwise maintained a record of good conduct and has paid all outstanding court costs, supervision fees, fines, and restitution as may have been ordered in all criminal cases in which he has been convicted. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(18), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-149. - Same-Appeals. 
(a)  A person whose license or permit application under this division is denied shall have the right to appeal. 
(b)  A person whose license or permit under this division is suspended or revoked shall have the right to appeal. 
(c)  The following procedures shall govern appeals authorized by this section: 
(1)  An appeal shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal, and shall be sworn to. 
(2)  An appeal shall be filed with the chief of police no later than the tenth day following the date of the denial or the date that the revocation/suspension orders are signed. 
(3)  After receiving an appeal, the chief of police shall immediately forward it and all pertinent records to the appeals officer designated by the city manager. 
(4)  An appeal shall stay a suspension or revocation. 
(5)  The appeals officer shall set a date for a hearing that is no later than the 20th day following the date the appeal is filed. 
(6)  The appeals officer shall issue notice of the hearing to the person filing the appeal and to the chief of police. 
(7)  The appeals officer shall be empowered to reverse or amend the decision of the hearings officer. 
(8)  The appeals officer shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law, and his decision shall also be in writing. He shall forward a copy of such findings and decision to the person making the appeal and to the chief of police. 
(9)  An appeal shall exhaust all administrative remedies. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(19), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-150. - Responsibilities of licensee-Recordkeeping. 
(a)  A licensee under this article shall keep written records on each vehicle it tows as a nonconsent tow. These records shall contain: 
(1)  The year, make, model, color, correct license plate number, state issuing the license and correct vehicle identification number of the vehicle; 
(2)  The date, time and location from which the vehicle was towed, and the name of the person who authorized the tow; 
(3)  The name of the tow truck driver that towed the vehicle, and the regular and tow truck license plate numbers of the tow truck that towed the vehicle; and 
(4)  All amounts charged for the towing of such vehicle, and the specific nature of each charge. 
(b)  The licensee, his agent or employee shall make the records required by this section available for inspection and copying by the chief of police or his designee upon his request, during the operating hours of the licensee. 
(c)  Records required by this section shall be kept under the care and custody of the licensee for at least two years from the date of the tow. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(20), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-151. - Same-Signage and posting. 
    Every holder of a nonconsent tow business license or driver's permit issued pursuant to this article, and every certificate holder shall comply with the following minimum signage requirements for nonconsent tows from parking facilities: 
(1)  These requirements shall apply only where notice of prohibited parking is given by signs. They shall not apply to tows made of vehicles parked in fire lanes or of vehicles obstructing an entrance, exit or aisle of a parking facility. They also shall not apply to tows made of vehicles when the vehicle's owner has actually received notice from the parking facility owner that the vehicle will be towed away if it is not removed. 
(2)  Signs shall be placed on the righthand side of each driveway access or curb cut allowing vehicular access to a parking facility. If there are no curbs or access barriers, signs shall be placed at intervals of not less than 25 feet around the perimeter of the parking facility, or that portion of the perimeter which is accessible by vehicles. 
(3)  Each sign shall be placed at a right angle so as to face entering traffic. They shall be placed no farther than five feet from the public right-of-way line, but shall not be within such right-of-way. 
(4)  Each sign shall be permanently installed on posts so that the bottom edge of the sign is no closer than five feet nor farther than seven feet from the ground. 
(5)  Each sign shall be a minimum of 18 inches wide by 24 inches deep. Their facings shall be fabricated out of weatherproof material. The letters on such signs shall be of a minimum height of two inches, of a contrasting color to the background and shall be light reflective. The background shall be white. 
(6)  Each sign shall state who may park in the facility, and shall further state that all others are prohibited and will be towed away at the owner's expense. The words "tow away zone" shall be included on each sign in capital letters of a minimum height of two inches. 
(7)  Each sign shall provide the name and current telephone number of the person or firm authorized to tow vehicles from the parking facility, and the name and current telephone number of the vehicle storage facility, if different from the person or firm authorized to tow vehicles. Alternatively, each sign may state the name and phone number of the parking facility owner if that person has knowledge of the location of the stored vehicle. 
(8)  Signs shall be continuously maintained at a parking facility for 24 hours prior to the towing or removing of any vehicle. However, this subsection shall not be deemed as giving proper notice to the owner of a vehicle parked on a parking facility prior to the installation of the signs and not subsequently moved by the owner. 
(9)  The provisions of this section shall be in addition to the requirements of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-2. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(21), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-152. - Towing charges. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he owns or operates a wrecker business and he fails to post conspicuously at the physical address of such business the fees charged by such business for nonconsent tows. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he knowingly places for storage a vehicle towed without the owner's consent at a vehicle storage facility that fails to post conspicuously the fees charged for nonconsent tows by such facility. 
(c)  A licensee, certificate holder, or an agent thereof commits an offense if it charges fees for nonconsent tows in excess of those stated on its itemized list of charges filed pursuant to this section. 
(d)  A licensee or a certificate holder shall submit all changes in its nonconsent tow fee schedule to the chief of police, and such changes shall be on file at least ten calendar days prior to becoming effective. Fees charged a vehicle owner shall be those that were effective on the date a vehicle was towed, not those effective on the date the vehicle was claimed. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(22), 7-21-92) 
Sec. 22-153. - Notice of statutory hearings. 
(a)  Upon initial contact with the owner of a vehicle which is the subject of a nonconsent tow, a wrecker service operator, a vehicle storage facility operator, or any employee or agent thereof shall give written notice to the vehicle owner of his right to a hearing pursuant to Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-3. 
(b)  The notice required by this section shall include a statement that the hearing must be requested in writing within six days of the date the vehicle was stored and that the request must be filed with a magistrate in whose jurisdiction the vehicle storage facility is located. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if he fails to provide notice as provided by this section. 
(Ord. No. O-92-867,  1(G)(23), 7-21-92) 
Secs. 22-154-22-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MASS GATHERING EVENTS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, adopted Feb. 17, 2009, amended Art. VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, Art. VI pertained to mass gatherings; outdoor music festivals, and derived from Code of 1980, ch. 4,  6(A-J); Ord. No. O-90-780,  1, 2, 7-3-90; Ord. No. O-04-1496,  2-10, 12-21-04. 
State Law reference- Mass gatherings outside municipalities, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 751. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-176. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Event sponsor means any person, group of persons, firm, corporation, partnership, or association that organizes, promotes or solicits funds for the organization or promotion of a mass gathering event. 
    Issuing officer means the city manager or his/her designated representative. 
    Mass gathering events means any outdoor meeting or gathering held inside the city limits or within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city in which more than 500 persons are present at any one time and who will remain at the location of the gathering for a period of more than eight continuous hours. This definition shall not apply to the following events: 
(1)  Public or private school gatherings such as sporting or educational events where the students are the primary participants; 
(2)  City approved, league sponsored sporting events held within a city owned park. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-177. - Conduct of event; minimum standards. 
    The following minimum standards shall apply in the conduct of mass gathering events permitted under this article: 
(1)  Water supply. The event sponsor shall provide access to a supply of potable water on the site where the event is taking place. 
(2)  Toilet facilities. The event sponsor shall provide toilet facilities and shall arrange for collection and cleaning at intervals of sufficient frequency to prevent the creation of a health hazard or public nuisance. 
(3)  Solid waste facilities. 
a.  The event sponsor shall arrange for solid waste facilities with the waste collection company holding a franchise with the city. 
b.  All solid waste shall be collected at such frequent intervals as may be necessary to maintain sanitary conditions at the site as determined by the building official. 
(4)  Noise control. Amplifying equipment shall be designed to control the noise level at the perimeter of the site on which the gathering shall take place and be so operated that at no time more than 70 decibels is registered on the "A" scale at slow response of a standard sound level meter which meets the specifications of the American National Standards Institute. 
(5)  Food sanitation. All food and beverages sold or furnished shall be in accordance with the standards of the Tarrant County Health Department. 
(6)  Medical and nursing care. When required by the city fire chief, the event sponsor shall provide one or more emergency aid stations, which shall be staffed and include suitable temporary shelter, supplies and equipment, at no cost to the city. 
(7)  Signage. Signage used in accordance with the event shall comply with the sign regulations of the city under the provisions for special event and promotional signage. Any signs not located on the actual premises where the event is being held shall only be approved upon the issuance of a sign permit from the building official. Signs advertising the event or directing potential customers to the event site are expressly prohibited from placement in the city rights-of-way. 
(8)  Tents. A separate tent permit shall be obtained from the building official in order to erect a tent. Any special event which includes the use of a tent, canopy, or temporary structure shall meet the requirements in the building code and fire code. Fire lanes for emergency equipment must be provided and the site prepared in a manner so as not to be a fire hazard as determined by the fire marshal. 
(9)  Alcohol. It is the responsibility of the applicant to obtain city approval for the possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages during a special event. For special events requiring a permit from the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission (TABC), a copy of the state permit shall be required prior to the issuance of a mass gathering permit. In accordance with the alcohol provisions in this Code, the city council shall have the authority to issue a temporary alcohol sales permit in conjunction with a mass gathering permit provided all city and state regulations are met. Prior to city council consideration of the alcohol permit, the police chief shall, notwithstanding any requirements of TABC, determine the amount, if necessary, of police officers required while alcohol is being served. The cost of any required police officers as part of this permit shall be paid in full by the event sponsor prior to issuance of the temporary alcohol sales permit. 
(10)  Fireworks/pyrotechnic displays. Any use of fireworks or pyrotechnic displays must show proof of application for a state permit and prior to issuance of a mass gathering permit. A permit from the fire marshal shall be obtained prior to the use of fireworks or pyrotechnics. 
(11)  City sponsorship. Should the event be officially sponsored or co-sponsored by the city, then certain standards of this chapter may be waived as determined by the issuing officer. 
(12)  Final site cleanup. At the conclusion of the mass gathering, the site shall be inspected by the building official for health and sanitation considerations. The event sponsor shall be responsible for the final site cleanup. The landowner, upon notification by the city of the existence of any unsanitary conditions shall immediately cause such conditions to be corrected. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Secs. 22-178-22-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 22-191. - Required. 
    No person may act as an event sponsor of a mass gathering event unless a permit has been issued by the city council under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-192. - Application-Filing; contents. 
(a)  An event sponsor desiring to hold a mass gathering event shall file a permit application with the issuing officer at least 60 days prior to the first day of the mass gathering event. 
(b)  The application for a permit under this article must include: 
(1)  The name and address of the event sponsor. 
(2)  A description of the mass gathering site. 
(3)  The name and address of the owner of the place where the mass gathering event is to be held and a letter signed by the property owner giving permission to the use the property for the mass gathering event. 
(4)  The dates and times of the mass gathering event. 
(5)  The maximum number of persons that the event sponsor will allow to attend the mass gathering event and a statement showing how the event sponsor plans to control the number of persons in attendance at the mass gathering event. 
(6)  A description of the nature of the event. 
(7)  A filing fee of $250.00 must be submitted with the application for a permit. 
(8)  The event sponsor shall attach a letter to the application which addresses the following: 
a.  Initial set-up times. 
b.  Controlling the number of persons in attendance at the mass gathering event. 
c.  Parking traffic control. 
d.  Street closures. 
e.  Compliance with health requirements regarding food and beverage services, including the provision for potable water. 
f.  Plans for emergency services, equipment and personnel. 
g.  Plans for event security. 
h.  Restroom facilities. 
i.  Solid waste collection arrangements. 
j.  The sale of alcoholic beverages and identifying minors attending the event. 
k.  clean-up after the event. 
(9)  Any other information requested by the issuing officer that they may deem necessary in order to consider the permit request. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-193. - Insurance, indemnification, surety bond. 
(a)  If an event is to be held on city-owned property, the event sponsor shall furnish the issuing officer with a certificate of insurance complying with minimum standards sufficient to protect city-owned property. 
(b)  The event sponsor for a mass gathering permit shall sign an agreement to indemnify and hold harmless the city, its officers, employees, agents, and representatives against all claims of liability and causes of action resulting from injury or damage to persons or property arising out of the mass gathering. 
(c)  The event sponsor may be required to post a surety bond in the assurance that the city property is cleaned and returned to the condition prior to the event. The issuing officer shall determine if the need for a bond exists and shall make the appropriate recommendation to the city council upon city council consideration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-194. - Same-Hearing. 
    Upon receipt of all information required under sections 22-192 and 22-193, the issuing officer shall set a date and time for a hearing before the city council on the application for a permit under this article. The hearing shall occur no later than 30 days prior to the event in question. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-195. - City council approval required. 
    After the hearing on the application for a permit under this article is completed, the city council shall grant or deny the permit. No permit for a mass gathering event shall be issued by the issuing officer unless the city council has approved the mass gathering event application. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-196. - Cash deposit. 
    As a condition precedent to the issuance of a permit under this article, the city council may require the event sponsor to make a cash deposit with the city to provide an adequate fund for the compensation of such security personnel as may be required to ensure the physical safety of persons and property of persons in attendance, as well as the persons and property of the community directly affected by the mass gathering or event. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-197. - Contents. 
    A permit, if issued, shall authorize the event sponsor to hold a mass gathering event at a specified place and at specified times. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Sec. 22-198. - Revocation. 
    At any time, the issuing officer may, after reasonable notice to the, event sponsor, revoke the permit on a finding that the failure to carry out the preparations will result in a serious threat to the health or safety of the community or the persons attending the event. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1710,  1, 2-17-09) 
Secs. 22-199-22-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-10-1765,  2, adopted Sept. 7, 2010, set out provisions intended for use as Ch. 22, Art. V. To avoid duplication, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Ch. 22, Art. VII, as set out herein. See also the Code Comparative Table. 

DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-211. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the purpose of this article to regulate sexually oriented businesses to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the citizens of the city, and to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent the concentration of sexually oriented businesses within the city. The provisions of this article have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on the content of any communicative materials, including sexually oriented materials. Similarly, it is neither the intent nor the effect of this article to restrict or deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by the First Amendment or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually oriented entertainment to their intended market. 
(Ord. No. O-10-1765,  2, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 22-212. - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following terms shall, for the purposes of this article, have the meanings indicated in this section. 
    Applicant means a person or persons listed as such on an application for a license as a sexually oriented business. 
    Business days means the days of the week from Monday through Friday, excluding legal holidays. 
    Chief of police means the chief of police, assistant chief of police, deputy chief of police or a designated acting chief of police. In Sections 22-231, 22-232 and 22-234 of this ordinance, chief of police shall also mean a member of the police department covert operations unit designated by the chief of police. 
    Church means a building, whether situated within the city or not, in which persons regularly assemble for religious worship and said building is intended primarily for purposes connected with such worship or for propagating a particular form of religious belief. 
    Customer means any person who: 
(1)  Is allowed to enter a sexually oriented business in return for the payment of an admission fee or any other form of consideration or gratuity; or 
(2)  Enters a sexually oriented business and purchases, rents or otherwise partakes of any merchandise, goods, entertainment or other services offered therein; or
