ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; parks and recreation, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Nuisances in or near home rule municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code  217.042; common and public nuisances, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code  125.001 et seq.; protection of public health, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code  122.006; minimum standards of sanitation and health protection measures, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code  341.001 et seq.; local regulation of sanitation, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code  342.001 et seq.; Texas Litter Abatement Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code  365.001 et seq.; pesticide regulation, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code  76.001 et seq.; noxious weed control districts, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code  78.001 et seq. 

Sec. 42-26. - Definition. 
    Any condition or occurrence which is dangerous to human life or health, or which renders the ground, the water, the air or food a hazard or injury to human life or health, or that is offensive to the senses, or that is or threatens to become detrimental to the public health is and shall constitute a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. O-91-813,  1(A), 4-16-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 42-27. - Acts declared nuisances. 
    The following acts or conditions are specifically declared to be nuisances. However, these declarations are not exclusive and any act or condition which is dangerous to human life or health, or which renders the ground, water, air, or food a hazard or injury to human life or health, or that is offensive to the senses, or that threatens to become detrimental to the public health shall be a nuisance even though not specifically declared a nuisance in this section: 
(1)  Keeping of animals under certain conditions. 
a.  Accumulations of manure. The keeping or harboring of any horses, cattle, sheep, goats, or any other animal, and allowing the manure or liquid discharges of such animals to collect or accumulate in an unclean or unsanitary manner is hereby declared to be a nuisance; provided, that nothing in this subsection shall be construed as to include manure deposits upon any private property for the purpose of cultivating same, when such deposits are maintained so as to prevent the breeding of flies. 
b.  Keeping of hogs. The keeping or harboring of hogs or swine is hereby declared to be a nuisance, with the exception of four adult registered potbellied pigs kept as domesticated pets. 
c.  Dog kennels within 300 feet of residences. Allowing more than four dogs to be housed, kept, raised or boarded at one time within 300 feet of any residence, other than the residence of the owner of the dogs, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
d.  Keeping of horses, cows, sheep, and goats. The stabling, pasturing, or keeping of any horse, cow, sheep or goat which does not meet the following criteria is hereby declared to be a nuisance: The total number of grazing animals shall not be more than two large or four small grazing animals per 15,000 square feet of contiguous land area the animal keeper owns or controls, on the condition that a paddock area is provided which is not less than 7,500 square feet per large grazing animal or 3,750 square feet per small grazing animal, for each animal which is turned out and that a minimum of 7,500 square feet of paddock area be provided in any case. 
e.  Keeping of grazing animals. The keeping of any grazing animal other than a horse, cow, sheep or goat is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
f.  Keeping of chickens. The keeping of a chicken or chickens within 50 feet of any residence or inhabited building is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
g.  Keeping of pigeons. The keeping or harboring of more than 75 pigeons, or failing to confine pigeons in proper cages or lofts maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Provided, however, pigeons bearing a seamless leg band issued by a recognized association of pigeon fanciers may be released for exercise or performance, upon the condition that the owner or person having possession of such pigeons shall not permit them to alight on any building whatsoever on the property of others. 
(2)  Discharge of liquid waste on streets. The accumulation or discharge onto any public street or private property of urine, liquid waste from stables, swill, water from privy vaults, water from sinks, wastewater, or any foul or nauseous waste of any kind whatsoever is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(3)  Accumulations of garbage and filth. The deposit or existence on or in any public or private building or property, of any putrid or unsound meat, pork, fish, hides, decayed vegetables or food, manure, ash heaps, garbage, offal, rubbish, dirt, or filth of any kind is hereby declared to be a nuisance, with the exception of compost piles (see section 42-27(1)a). 
(4)  Common use of halls, water closets, etc., in residences. The renting, leasing, hiring out to be occupied or the occupancy of any building or part thereof as a home or residence of more than two families, living independent of one another, giving to each family or person therein the common right to halls, yards, water closets or privies or some of them, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(5)  Burning. The burning of any manure, straw, garbage or any refuse of any kind or description, except within an incinerator approved by the state department of health and the city, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(6)  Dead animals. 
a.  Slaughtered animals. The keeping of any unclean carcasses of hogs, cattle, or other animals in any slaughterhouse, meat market, meat shop or otherwise in an unclean or unsanitary manner is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
b.  Green or unsalted hides. The keeping of any green or unsalted hides for a period exceeding six hours is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
c.  Rendering materials from dead animals. Conducting a business or any part thereof concerning bone crushing, bone boiling, bone grinding, bone burning, bone drying, fat burning, fat boiling, fat rendering, fat drying, gut cleaning, or the making of glue or the manufacture of fertilizer material of any kind or description from any dead animal or parts thereof, or boiling of offal, swill, fat, or grease of any description is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(7)  Filthy drains, leaking garbage receptacles, etc. Allowing any unclean, stinking, foul, defective, or filthy drain, ditch, tank or gutter, or any leaking or broken slop, garbage or manure boxes or receptacles of like character on any property is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(8)  Accumulation of offensive materials. The deposit or existence of any dirt gathered in cleaning yards, waste of mills or factories, damaged merchandise, wet, broken, or leaking barrels, casks or boxes, or used building materials is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(9)  Depositing or throwing articles into sewer inlet. The depositing, throwing, or insertion into any sewer inlet or privy vault, which has a sewer connection, of any article whatsoever that may cause the sewer to choke up, stop up, or otherwise be rendered inoperative in whole or part is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(10)  Vehicles hauling garbage, swill, or other offensive matter. The transportation of manure, garbage, swill, ashes, cinders, or other loose material in any of the streets of the city on a vehicle other than in a good and substantially tight box thereon, the size of which shall be not less than 24 inches high and the tailboard not less than 24 inches high, so that no portion of such manure or other loose material shall be scattered or thrown into the street, or hauling garbage, swill, or other offensive material in a vehicle which does not have the box thereon closely covered with sufficient covering, so closely fitted as to prevent the escape or flying about of any of the contents or effluvia therefrom is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(11)  Ponds or pools of unwholesome water. Creating or allowing the existence upon any property of a pond or pool or container of unwholesome, impure, or offensive water or water which is conducive to the breeding of mosquitoes, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(12)  Impure or unwholesome wells or cisterns. Allowing the existence of any well or cistern to exist upon any property whenever a chemical or bacteriological analysis shows that the water of the well or cistern is impure or unwholesome is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(13)  Noise nuisances. 
a.  Any unreasonably loud, disturbing, unnecessary noise which causes material distress, discomfort or injury to persons of ordinary sensibilities in the immediate vicinity thereof is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
b.  Any noise of such character, intensity, and continued duration which substantially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of private homes by persons of ordinary sensibilities is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
c.  The following acts, among others, are declared to be nuisances, but such enumerations shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
1.  Musical instruments. The playing of any radio, phonograph or other musical instrument in such manner or with such volume, particularly during the hours between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of persons of ordinary sensibilities in any dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence. 
2.  Loudspeakers and amplifiers. The use of any stationary loudspeaker or amplifier of such intensity as to annoy and disturb persons of ordinary sensibilities in the immediate vicinity thereof; the use of any stationary loudspeaker or amplifier operated on any weekday between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time on Sunday. 
3.  Animals and birds. The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort and repose of any person of ordinary sensibilities in the immediate vicinity. 
4.  Operation of vehicles. The running of any automobile, motorcycle, or other vehicle so out of repair, so loaded, or in such manner as to create loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, jarring, or rattling noise or vibrations. 
5.  Steam whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of time to begin or stop work, or as a warning of danger. 
6.  Exhaust without mufflers. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor vehicle or boat engine, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
7.  Devices operated by compressed air. The use of any mechanical device operated by compressed air, unless the noise to be created is effectively muffled and reduced. 
8.  Construction work. The erection, including excavation, demolition, alteration, or repair work, of any building other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public safety and convenience, and then only by permit from the city council, which permit may be renewed by the council during the time the emergency exists. 
9.  Near schools and hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school or institution of learning while such school or institution of learning is in session, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the working of such institutions, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such manner indicating that the street is a school or hospital street. 
10.  Loading and unloading vehicles, destruction of boxes, etc. The creation of any loud and excessive noise in connection with the loading or unloading of any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates, and containers. 
11.  Peddlers, hawkers, etc. The raucous shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers, and vendors, which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
12.  Use of drums, loudspeakers, etc., to attract attention. The use of any drum, loudspeaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by the creation of noise to any performance, show, or sale of merchandise. 
13.  Sounding of sirens, horns, signaling devices. The sounding of any siren, horn, or other signal device on any automobile, ambulance, truck, motorcycle, bus, or other vehicle in the city, except as a danger or warning signal to persons or animals using the streets, sidewalks, and public thoroughfares; the creation by means of any such signal device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound for any unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. 
14.  Railroad whistles. The blowing or sounding of any steam whistle, horn, or signal device on any engine, locomotive car, or vehicle adapted to the rails of a railroad in the city, except as a warning or a danger signal to persons or animals approaching, crossing, or using the tracks of the railroad. 
15.  Outdoor recreational or sports activities. Engaging in or allowing the playing of outdoor organized recreational activities or team sports between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., in an area which is not a public park and which is within 500 feet of property zoned for residential use; provided, however, that permission allowing the playing of recreational activities or outdoor sports and illumination of playing fields until 12:00 midnight only during weekends and holidays on property within 500 feet of property zoned for residential use and not a public park, shall be granted up to four nights per year by obtaining written permission from the city manager and shall not constitute a nuisance. A copy of the special permit granted by the city manager shall be kept on record at city hall for a period not less than 24 months from the issuance date of the special use/exception permit. 
(14)  Outdoor lighting. 
a.  The illumination of or allowing the illumination of any area not a public park by lighting devices designed or located for the purpose of lighting an area for the playing of outdoor organized recreational activities or team sports between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. within 500 feet of property zoned for residential use is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. 
b.  Exceptions. Permission allowing the playing of recreational activities or outdoor sports and illumination of playing fields until 12:00 midnight only during weekends and holidays on property within 500 feet of property zoned for residential use and not a public park, shall be granted up to four nights per year by obtaining written permission from the city manager and shall not constitute a nuisance. A copy of the special permit granted by the city manager shall be kept on record at city hall for a period not less than 24 months from the issuance date of the special use/exception permit. 
(Ord. No. O-91-813,  1(B), 4-16-91; Ord. No. O-93-918,  1, 2, 8-31-93; Ord. No. O-98-1101,  1, 9-1-98) 
Sec. 42-28. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person who is the owner of or in control of any occupied or unoccupied premises shall permit or allow the existence of any nuisance thereon. 
(b)  No person shall commit or perform any act which constitutes or creates a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. O-91-813,  1, 4-16-91) 
Sec. 42-29. - Abatement of nuisances, procedure; liens; foreclosure. 
(a)  Notification. Whenever any nuisance exists upon any property within the city, the city manager or his designee shall notify the owner or occupant of the premises on which the nuisance exists of the violation of the city Code and order the abatement of the nuisance. Such notice and order shall be given: 
(1)  Personally to the owner in writing; 
(2)  By letter addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address; or 
(3)  By publication at least twice within ten consecutive days if personal service cannot be obtained and the owner's post office address is unknown. 
(b)  Abatement. If the owner of the property does not comply with the city Code and the order issued under this section within ten days of the notice of violation, the city may do the work or make the improvements required, and pay for the work done or improvements made and charge the expenses thereof to the owner of the property. 
(c)  Lien for costs. Where the nuisance abated: 
(1)  Concerns the filling, draining, and regulating of any place in the city that is unwholesome, contains stagnant water, or is in any other condition that may produce disease; 
(2)  Concerns the making, filling, altering or repairing of sewers and privies; 
(3)  Concerns the mode and material for constructing sewers and privies; 
(4)  Concerns the cleaning and disinfecting of sewers and privies; 
(5)  Concerns the cleaning of a building, establishment, or ground of filth, carrion, or other impure or unwholesome matter; or 
(6)  Concerns requiring the owner of a lot in the city to keep the lot free from junk, rubbish and other objectionable, unsightly or unsanitary matter. 
The city council may assess the expenses incurred against the real estate on which the work is done or improvements made to alleviate or abate the nuisance. To obtain a lien, the mayor, city health authority or city official designated by the mayor shall file a statement of expenses with the county clerk. Such lien shall be security for the expenditures made and interest shall accrue on such expenditures at the rate of ten percent per annum on the amount due from the date of payment by the city. 
(d)  Foreclosure. The city may bring a suit for foreclosure of the lien in the name of the city to recover the expenditures and interest due and in such suit the statement of expenses or a certified copy of the statement shall be prima facie proof of the expenses incurred by the city in doing the work or making the improvements. 
(Ord. No. O-91-813,  1, 4-16-91; Ord. No. O-98-1101,  2, 9-1-98) 
Sec. 42-30. - Junked vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Antique auto means a passenger car or truck that was manufactured in 1925 or before or a passenger car or truck that is at least 35 years old. 
    Collector means the owner of one or more antique or special interest vehicles who collects, purchases, acquires, trades, or disposes of special interest or antique vehicles or parts of them for personal use in order to restore, preserve, and maintain an antique or special interest vehicle for historic interest. 
    Junked vehicle means a motor vehicle as defined in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d-11: 
(1)  That is inoperative; and 
(2)  That does not have lawfully affixed to it either an unexpired license plate or a valid motor vehicle safety inspection certificate, that is wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled or discarded, or that remains inoperable for a continuous period of more than 45 days. 
    Special interest vehicle means a motor vehicle of any age that has not been altered or modified from original manufacturer's specifications and, because of its historic interest, is being preserved by hobbyists. 
(b)  Public nuisance. 
(1)  A junked vehicle or vehicle part that is located in a place where it is visible from a public place or public right-of-way is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the general public, tends to reduce the value of private property, invites vandalism, creates fire hazards, constitutes an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors, and is detrimental to the economic welfare of the city by producing urban blight adverse to the maintenance and continued development of the city and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. It is not a public nuisance to maintain a vehicle or a vehicle part that is completely enclosed within a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or other public or private property, a vehicle or a vehicle part that is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer or junkyard, or an unlicensed, operable or inoperable antique or special interest vehicle stored by a collector on the collector's property, if the vehicle and the outdoor storage area are maintained in a manner so that they do not constitute a health hazard and are screened from ordinary public view by means of a fence, rapidly growing trees, shrubbery or other appropriate means. 
(2)  A person commits an offense if that person maintains a public nuisance as determined under this section. Each and every day such nuisance continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(3)  A person who commits an offense under this section is, upon conviction, subject to a fine not to exceed $200.00. On conviction, the court shall order removal and abatement of the nuisance. 
(c)  Summary procedure for abating public nuisance. 
(1)  Upon determination by the police chief that a junked vehicle located on private property constitutes a public nuisance, the police chief or his designee, who must be a regularly salaried, full-time employee of the city, shall give written notice stating the nature of the public nuisance and that the public nuisance must be removed and abated within ten days of the notice or a request for a public hearing before the city council must be made within such ten-day period. Such written notice shall be mailed by certified mail, with a five-day return requested, to the last known registered owner of the junked vehicle, any lienholder of record, and the owner or occupant of the private premises on which the public nuisance exists. If the post office address of the last known registered owner of the motor vehicle is unknown, notice to the last known registered owner may be placed on the motor vehicle, or, if the last known registered owner is physically located, the notice may be hand delivered. If any notice is returned undelivered by the United States post office, official action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than ten days after the date of return. 
(2)  Upon the determination by the police chief that a junked vehicle located on public property constitutes a public nuisance, the police chief or his designee, who must be a regularly salaried full-time employee of the city, shall give written notice stating the nature of the public nuisance and that the nuisance must be removed and abated within ten days or a request for a public hearing before the city council must be made before the expiration of the ten-day period. The notice shall be mailed by certified mail, with a five-day return requested, to the last known registered owner of the junked vehicle, any lienholder of record, and the owner or occupant of the public premises or the owner or occupant of the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way on which the public nuisance exists. If the post office address of the last known registered owner of the motor vehicle is unknown, notice to the last known registered owner may be placed on the motor vehicle, or, if the last known registered owner is physically located, the notice may be hand delivered. If the notice is returned undelivered by the United States post office, official action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than ten days after the date of the return. 
(3)  The notices given pursuant to subsections (c)(1) and (c)(2) of this section shall also designate a time and place at which a public hearing shall be held before the removal of the vehicle or vehicle part as a public nuisance. Such hearing shall be held before the police chief of the city; provided, however, if a hearing is requested by the owner or occupant of the public or private premises or owner or occupant of the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way upon which the vehicle is located within ten days after service of the notice to abate the nuisance, such hearing shall be held before the city council. At the hearing it is presumed, unless demonstrated otherwise by the owner, that the vehicle is inoperable. A resolution or order requiring removal of the vehicle or the vehicle part must include a description of the vehicle and the correct identification number and license number of the vehicle if the information is available at the site. 
(d)  Removed vehicle not to be reconstructed. After a vehicle or a vehicle part has been removed pursuant to this section it shall not be reconstructed or made operable. 
(e)  Notice to state department of transportation. The city shall give notice to the state department of transportation not later than the fifth day after the date of removal, which shall specify the identity of the vehicle or vehicle part removed. 
(Ord. No. O-91-813,  1, 4-16-91) 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4477-9a,  5.01 et seq.; state department of transportation, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6663. 
Sec. 42-31. - Weeds, grass and uncultivated plants. 
(a)  Definition of terms. 
    Parkway means the portion of any street between the roadway and the private property line. 
(b)  Prohibition. 
(1)  Permitting or allowing weeds, grass or any plant that is not cultivated to grow to a height in excess of eight inches upon any property within the corporate limits of the City of Colleyville or to leave weeds, grass or uncultivated plants in excess of eight inches on such premises after they have been cut is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(2)  A person commits an offense if the person owns, occupies or controls any property within the corporate limits of the City of Colleyville upon which weeds, grass or any plant that is not cultivated exceed eight inches in height or if weeds, grass or uncultivated plants in excess of eight inches are allowed to remain on such premises after they have been cut. 
(3)  A person commits an offense if the person owns, occupies or controls any property within the corporate limits of the City of Colleyville and fails to maintain the parkway adjacent to the property free of weeds, grass or uncultivated plants that exceed eight inches in height or if weeds, grass or uncultivated plants in excess of eight inches are allowed to remain on such premises after they have been cut. 
(4)  In the case of agricultural tracts of five acres or larger and undeveloped residential subdivisions containing more than four lots and/or residential subdivisions where public improvements have been approved by the city and more than 20 percent of all lots approved for residential use are vacant, this section will be satisfied if the hay or grass is kept mowed to a height no greater than 12 inches for a distance of 100 feet around the entire perimeter of the tract. 
(c)  Abatement. 
(1)  The city manager or his designee is hereby authorized to give notice to the owner of any property which is in violation of the provisions of subsection 42-31(b), instructing the owner to abate the nuisance. 
(2)  If the owner of the property does not comply with the provisions of an abatement notice issued by the city manager or his designee within ten days after the date the notice is received, the city manager or his designee may: 
a.  Enter the property and do or cause to be done the work required to abate the nuisance; and 
b.  Pay for the work done and charge the expenses to the owner of the property or assess the owner a weed abatement fee in accordance with article II, section 2-26 of the City of Colleyville Code of Ordinances. 
(3)  The notice must be given: 
a.  Personally to the owner in writing; or 
b.  By letter addressed to the owner at the owner's last known address as shown on the city tax rolls; or 
c.  If personal service cannot be obtained, or the owner's post office address is unknown: 
1.  By publication at least twice within ten consecutive days; or 
2.  By posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the property to which the violation relates; or 
3.  If the property contains no buildings, by posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates. 
(4)  Notice will be deemed to have been received: 
a.  For personal service, as of the date the notice was given personally to the owner; 
b.  For mailed notice, three days after date of postmark; 
c.  For notice by publication, on the date that the last notice was published in the official newspaper; or 
d.  For notice by posting, ten days after the notice was posted. 
(5)  In the notice of a violation, the city manager or his designee may inform the owner that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, the city without further notice may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property. 
(6)  If a violation covered by a notice under subsection (c)(5) occurs within the one-year period, and the city manager or his designee has not been informed in writing by the owner of an ownership change, then the city without notice may take any action permitted by subsections (c)(2)a., b. and assess the expenses as provided by subsection 42-31(e). 
(d)  Property under development. 
(1)  Before any application for change of zoning, platting or replatting is accepted, all liens and charges arising under the terms of this section shall be satisfied and all concerned properties shall be in compliance with subsection 42-31(b) hereof. 
(2)  If the city has issued a permit and the property for which such permit was issued is in violation of subsection 42-31(b) hereof, the city manager or his designee may revoke the permit until such a nuisance has been abated. 
(3)  Such actions shall not defer any other remedies or penalties which may be applicable under this section. 
(e)  Assessment of expenses; lien. 
(1)  All expenses incurred by the city to abate high weeds, grass or uncultivated plants, including the cost of giving notice as required, shall initially be paid by the city and charged to the owner of the property. If the charge is not paid to the city within 30 days after billing, it will become a charge against the property and the city may file a lien upon the property. 
(2)  To obtain a lien upon the property, the city manager or his designee shall file a statement of expenses with the county clerk for the county in which the property is located. The lien statement shall state the name of the owner, if known, and the legal description of the property. The lien attaches upon the filing of the lien statement with the county clerk. 
(3)  The lien shall be security for the expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten percent per annum on the amount due from the date of payment by the city. 
(4)  The lien is inferior only to: 
a.  Tax liens; and 
b.  Liens for street improvements. 
(5)  The city may bring a suit for foreclosure of the lien in the name of the city to recover the expenditures and interest due and in said suit the statement of expenses or a certified copy of the statement shall be prima facie proof for the expenses incurred by the municipality in doing the work or making the improvements. 
(f)  Penalty. An offense as defined under section 42-31 is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. Each separate occurrence of a violation or each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-98-1101,  3, 9-1-98; Ord. No. O-08-1677,  2, 3, 5-6-08; Ord. No. O-08-1698,  3, 4, 10-21-08) 
Cross reference- Planting and maintenance of trees, etc.,  99-51 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Required construction standards for commercial buildings. 
(a)  Exterior walls. The exterior walls of all commercial buildings constructed within the city limits shall be of at least 75 percent masonry, glass, or other equivalent material. 
(b)  Applicability. For the purpose of this section, the construction of a commercial building shall include but shall not be limited to all initial construction of a commercial building or any reconstruction, remodeling, or other modification of any existing commercial building, or the conversion to a commercial use of any preexisting building. For the purpose of this section, a "commercial building" shall mean and include any building which is intended to be used or which is actually used for any activity involving the offering, buying, selling, manufacturing, assembly, trading, fabricating, delivering of goods and/or services, or any other activity, for profit as part of a business or commercial activity engaged in for gain or livelihood. 
(c)  Variances. The city council may grant a variance from the requirements of subsection (a) of this section if the city council finds that: 
(1)  The nature, type, and operation of the business or businesses to be conducted within the commercial building is not inherently susceptible to conflagration; 
(2)  The design and location of the commercial building is such that masonry, glass, or equivalent construction would not facilitate the control of a fire in such building by the fire department; and 
(3)  The structure is located in such an isolated area that there would be no danger of damage or injury to adjacent or surrounding property or improvements in the event of fire. 
(Code 1980, ch. 6,  7) 
Sec. 46-2. - Limitation on use of roofing materials in multifamily residences. 
    Roof assemblies shall be divided into the classes defined below. Class A, B, C roof assemblies and roof coverings required to be listed by this section shall be tested in accordance with ASTM E or UL 790. In addition, fire-retardant-treated wood roof coverings shall be tested in accordance with ASTM D 2898. The minimum roof coverings installed on buildings shall comply with Table 1505.1 listed Section 1505.1 of the International Building Code. 
a.  (footnote) Unless otherwise required in accordance with the Urban Wildland Interface Code or due to the location of the building within a fire district in accordance with Appendix D of the International Building Code. 
    Section 1505.1; Fire Classification, International Building Code, amend footnote b and c to read as follows: 
a.  All individual replacement shingles or shakes shall be in compliance with the rating required by Table 1505.1, International Building Code. 
b.  Non-classified roof coverings shall be permitted on buildings of U occupancies having not more than 120 square foot of projected roof area. When exceeding 120 square foot of Projected roof area, buildings of U occupancies may use non-rated non-combustible roof coverings. 
(Code 1980, ch. 6,  8; Ord. No. O-02-1348,  2, 7-2-02) 
Secs. 46-3-46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE CODE 

Sec. 46-31. - International Fire Code-Adopted. 
    The City of Colleyville hereby adopts the 2012 edition of the International Fire Code, including Appendix Chapters A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I published by the International Code Council, Inc., save and except such portions as are deleted or amended by this section, and the same are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1980, ch. 6,  1(A); Ord. No. O-02-1348,  3, 7-2-02; Ord. No. O-05-1520,  2, 4-19-05; Ord. No. O-14-1938,  1, 11-5-14) 
Secs. 46-32-46-34.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-14-1938,  1, adopted November 5, 2014, did not specifically amend the code. Therefore, at the editor's discretion,  46-32-46-34.1, which pertained to same-enforcement, same-definitions, same-conflicting provisions, and same-amendments, were repealed without replacement. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. See section 46-31, International Fire Code-Adopted. 
Sec. 46-35. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the code official disapproves or refuses to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provision of the code adopted in section 46-31, International Fire Code, does not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code adopted in section 46-31, International Fire Code, have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the person that applied for the permit may appeal from the decision of the code official to the City of Colleyville Contractor's Board within 30 days from the date of the code official decision. 
(Code 1980, ch. 6,  1(E); Ord. No. O-02-1348,  8, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 46-36. - Establishment of limits of districts in which storage of flammable or combustible liquids is prohibited. 
    The storage of flammable or combustible liquids in an outside above ground storage is prohibited. 
    Exceptions: 
(1)  An exception may be granted by the fire marshal during an emergency operation, at construction sites, and other locations where underground installations cannot be utilized. At no time will the sale or distribution of flammable or combustible liquids be allowed from above ground storage tanks by gravity, portable pump powered by vehicle batteries or pneumatic pressure. 
(2)  Above ground fuel tanks that comply with International Fire Code, Chapter 34, may be allowed for commercial and retail purposes when permitted by the fire marshal. 
(3)  The storage of flammable or combustible liquids at construction sites shall require a permit from the fire marshal's office. All fuel tanks shall be at least ten feet off the roadway. 
(Code 1980, ch. 6,  1(F); Ord. No. O-02-1348,  9, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 46-37. - Establishment of limits of districts in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited. 
(a)  The storage of explosives or blasting agents within the city limits is prohibited without a permit from the fire marshal. 
(b)  No motor vehicle designed or utilized to transport explosives or blasting agents, or required a Department of Transportation (DOT) warning placards, shall be parked within the city limits without a fire marshals' permit. 
    Exception: Vehicles may be parked for one hour for the purpose of loading or off loading cargo or eating a meal. 
(Code 1980, ch. 6,  1(H); Ord. No. O-02-1348,  10, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 46-38. - Establishment of limits in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases is restricted. 
(a)  The storage, sale, and distribution of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) prohibited in all heavily populated and congested commercial areas of the city. 
(b)  The storage, sale, and distribution or installation of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) systems on vehicles shall meet the regulations and guidelines of the Texas Railroad Commission, Chapter 38 of the International Fire Code, NFPA 58, and the International Fuel Gas Code. 
(c)  The storage, sale, and distribution of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) must have a permit from the fire marshal. 
(d)  A permit shall be required for the installation, alteration and/or removal of a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) tank. The permit shall be obtained before the start of any work and the cost of the permit shall be by the Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinance, City of Colleyville, Texas. 
(e)  Where portable liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) containers are required for jewelry repair, dental labs, portable cookers and other services, individual containers shall not exceed 20-pound water capacity and the aggregate capacity on premises shall not exceed 60 pounds water capacity (three containers). Each container shall be separated from other containers by a distance of not less than 20 feet. 
    Exception: Such events where commercial outdoor cooking is required, provided a permit is issued by the fire marshals' office and the site is inspected by the code official. 
(Code 1980, ch. 6,  1(G); Ord. No. O-02-1348,  11, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 46-38.1. - Establishing a standard and limits for compressed natural gas (CNG). 
(a)  The storage of compressed natural gas (CNG) is prohibited in all heavily populated and congested commercial areas of the city. 
(b)  The storage, sale, distribution or installation of vehicular fuel systems on vehicles shall be in accordance with the International Fuel Gas Code, NFPA 52, and related standard and regulation of the International Fire Code, and the International Fuel Gas Code. 
(c)  The storage, sale, distribution, removal, alteration or modification of a compressed natural gas (CNG) must have a site inspection before the work begins. 
(d)  A permit is required from the fire marshals' office. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1348,  11, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 46-38.2. - Liquefied natural gas (LNG), establishing a standard and limits for liquefied natural gas (LNG). 
(a)  The storage of liquefied natural gas (LNG) is prohibited in all heavily populated and congested commercial areas of the city. 
(b)  The storage, sale, distribution, or installation of a vehicular fuel system shall be in accordance with the International Fuel Gas Code, Texas Railroad Commission, NFPA 55, NFPA 57, and related Chapters of the International Fire Code. 
(c)  Any storage, sale, distribution, shall require a permit from the fire marshal's office. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1348,  11, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 46-39. - New materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
    The fire chief, fire marshal and the building official shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, and new materials, processes or occupancies for which permits are required. The committee shall review codes adopted to determine if the product meets or exceeds the code standards. The fire marshal shall post such materials listing in a conspicuous place at the office of the fire administration and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1348,  12, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 46-40. - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this code shall be fined as provided for in section 1-6 of the Code of Ordinance, City of Colleyville, Texas. 
    Now, be it known that chapter 46 of the Code of Ordinance, City of Colleyville, Texas, shall remain in full force and effect, except where amended by this ordinance, and 
    That any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined a sum not to exceed $2,000.00. Each and every day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
    That the city secretary is hereby authorized and directed to cause publication of the descriptive caption and penalty clause hereof as an alternative method of publication provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1348,  13, 7-2-02) 
Chapter 50 - FLOODS[1]
