ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1-58-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 58-26. - Compensation of members; bond; oath. 
    The compensation of the members of the police department shall be payable at a time and in a sum to be fixed by the city council, subject to change from time to time by the council, and before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, the members of such department shall give bond if a bond shall be required by the council, in such sum as may be prescribed by the council, conditioned as the council may deem best for the efficiency of the public service. The members of the police department shall take and subscribe to the oath of office prescribed by the Constitution of the State of Texas for state officials. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(A)) 
State Constitution reference- Official oath, art. XVI,  1. 
Sec. 58-27. - Filling of vacancies. 
    In case of a vacancy for any cause in the police department other than the chief of police, the chief shall appoint some person to fill such vacancy. The person appointed shall meet all requirements prescribed by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(B)) 
State Law reference- Commission on law enforcement officer standards and education, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 415. 
Sec. 58-28. - Acting chief of police. 
    In case of vacancy, absence, sickness, or inability to act on the part of the chief of police, the city manager, with the approval of the city council, shall designate some other member of the force, or other suitable person, as acting chief of police during the period of such absence, sickness, or inability to act, and such person shall exercise all the rights, powers, and duties of the chief of police during such period; provided however, that if the city manager is unable to secure a qualified person to fulfill the duties of the chief of police and in the interest of the health, safety, and welfare of the city and its inhabitants, the city manager shall fulfill the duties of such office until such time as a qualified person is available. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(N)) 
Sec. 58-29. - Powers of police officers. 
(a)  The chief of police and all police officers and other members of the police department shall be and they are hereby vested with all the power and authority given to them as peace officers under the laws of the state in taking cognizance of and in enforcing the criminal laws of the state and the ordinances and regulations of the city within the limits of the city, and it shall be the duty of such officers to be active in quelling riots, disorders, and disturbances of the peace within the limits of the city, and to take into custody all persons so offending against the public peace. Such officers shall further use their best endeavors to prevent the commission within the city of offenses against the laws of the state and of the ordinances and regulations of the city; to observe and enforce all such laws, ordinances, and regulations; to detect and arrest offenders against the same; to preserve the good order of the city and to secure the inhabitants thereof from violence, and the property therein from injury. Such officers shall have no power or authority in civil matters, but shall execute any criminal warrant or warrant of arrest that may be placed in their hands by the duly constituted authorities of the city. Such officers shall not receive any fee or other compensation for any services rendered in the performance of duty, other than the salary paid by the city, except upon the approval of the city council, nor shall they receive a fee as witness in any case arising under the laws of the state or under the ordinances or regulations of the city and prosecuted in the municipal court of the city. 
(b)  All police officers of the city shall have like power with the chief of police to execute all writs and processes issuing out of the municipal court. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(D), (I)) 
Sec. 58-30. - Attendance of police at municipal court. 
    The chief of police or one of the members of the police department selected by the chief of police shall attend every session of the municipal court, and shall promptly and faithfully execute all writs and processes issued from the municipal court. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(C)) 
Sec. 58-31. - Uniforms and badges. 
    The chief of police shall prescribe the uniforms and badges for the members of the police force, and direct the manner in which the members of the police force shall be armed. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(L)) 
Sec. 58-32. - Reserve police department. 
    Pursuant to the direction of section 7.03(B) of the Charter, members of the city reserve police department are hereby authorized to act as police officers for the city. The city council hereby adopts the constitution of the reserve police department of the city, which is incorporated in this article for all purposes. Any modification, change, or alteration of the constitution of the reserve police department shall be subject to the approval of the city council. Notwithstanding any provision of such constitution to the contrary, all reserve police officers shall be subject to the control and direction of the chief of police, and may be removed or denied membership in the city reserve police department at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(P)) 
State Law reference- Police reserve force, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code  341.012. 
Sec. 58-33. - Obstruction of justice. 
    The chief of police, police officers and other members of the police department shall arrest all persons who shall obstruct or interfere with them in the execution of the duties of their offices, or who shall be guilty of any disorderly conduct whatsoever. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(H)) 
State Law reference- Obstructing governmental operation, V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 38; disorderly conduct, V.T.C.A., Penal Code  42.01. 
Sec. 58-34. - Arrests without warrant. 
    The chief of police, police officers and other members of the police department may, without warrant, arrest any offender or alleged offender in the following cases: 
(1)  When any felony or disturbance, affray or breach of the peace, or violation of any city ordinance, is committed within the view or presence of the member of the police department making the arrest. 
(2)  When a felony or breach of the peace has been committed within the presence or view of a magistrate and such magistrate shall verbally order the arrest of the offender. 
(3)  When it is represented to a member of the police department by some creditable person that a felony or a disturbance, affray or breach of the peace, or violation of some city ordinance, has been committed, and that the offenders will probably escape if the arrest is delayed to procure a warrant. 
(4)  When persons are found in suspicious places and under circumstances which reasonably show that such persons have been guilty of a felony, violation of V.T.C.A., Penal Code  42.01 et seq., breach of the peace, or offense under V.T.C.A., Penal Code  49.02, or threaten or are about to commit an offense against the laws. 
(5)  When authorized by law. 
The foregoing enumeration is not intended and shall not be construed to exclude the right and authority of such officers to make arrests without warrant in all cases coming within the general provisions of this section, and in all such cases such person may be arrested without warrant and held to be dealt with according to law. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(J)(1)-(4)) 
State Law reference- Arrest without warrant, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. ch. 14. 
Sec. 58-35. - Arrested persons to be taken before magistrate. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, in all cases of arrest without warrant, the officer making the arrest shall immediately take the person arrested before the magistrate who ordered the arrest, or if the arrest was made without an order, then before the nearest or most accessible magistrate having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(K)) 
State Law reference- Offender taken before magistrate, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 14.06. 
Sec. 58-36. - Authority to take bail. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to take suitable and sufficient bail for appearance before the municipal court of any person charged with an offense within the jurisdiction of the court. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(F)) 
Sec. 58-37. - Control of city jail. 
    The chief of police shall have control and management of the city jail. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(E)) 
Sec. 58-38. - Authority to close public places. 
    The chief of police, in order to prevent a breach of the peace, or to preserve quiet and good order, shall have the authority to close any theater, barroom, drinking house, or any other place or building of public resort, and in the prevention and suppression of crime and the arrest of offenders within the city, he shall have like power and jurisdiction and authority as the sheriff of the county under the laws of the state. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(G)) 
Sec. 58-39. - Relief fund may be created. 
    The council may at its discretion provide for the relief of members of the police department temporarily or permanently disabled in the discharge of their duties; and shall also have the right to provide for the organization and administration of a pension fund to provide for old, disabled, and infirm members of the police force, under such system, rules and regulations as may be deemed advisable, whenever the finances of the city will justify the undertaking of this service. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(O)) 
Sec. 58-40. - Special police force. 
    Whenever the mayor shall deem it necessary, in order to enforce the laws of the city or to avert danger to or to protect life or property, in case of riot, or any outbreak or calamity or great public disturbance, or when he has reason to fear any serious violation of law and order, or any damage to the city or the inhabitants thereof, he shall have the power to summon into service as a special police force all or as many of the citizens as in his judgment or discretion may be necessary and proper, and such summons may be made verbally or by proclamation. Such special police force shall be subject to the orders of the mayor and shall have the same power and authority while on duty as a police officer, as regular police officers, and shall receive as compensation a sum not to exceed $5.00 for each day in actual service. 
(Code 1980, ch. 8,  2(M)) 
Secs. 58-41-58-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL COURT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09-1735,  1-3, 6, 7, adopted November 17, 2009, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as article III,  58-66-58-69 is at the discretion of the editor.  Section 7 of Ord. No. O-09-1735 states that the Municipal Court of Record No. 1 of the city is created commencing January 1, 2010. 

Sec. 58-66. - Municipal court. 
(a)  Creation. There is hereby created and established a court designated as a "Municipal Court of Record No. 1" of the City of Colleyville, Texas (the "city"), with all such powers and duties are now, or may hereafter, be prescribed by the laws of the state and ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Judge and associate judges. 
(1)  The city council, by majority vote, shall by ordinance appoint a Texas-licensed attorney to act as judge of the municipal court. The judge of the municipal court shall serve at the discretion of the city council. Said initial appointee shall hold a term of office corresponding to the unexpired term of the mayor, and every two years thereafter a municipal judge shall be appointed for a term of two years. 
(2)  The city council may appoint one or more persons to sit for the regular judge of the municipal court or for the presiding judge or any of the associate judges of such court, while such judge or judges, any or all, are temporarily unable to act for any reason. Such appointee or appointees shall possess the same qualifications required of the regular municipal judge, and shall have all the powers and duties of such office. 
(c)  Municipal court clerk. A municipal court clerk for the municipal court shall be appointed by the city manager. The municipal court clerk shall issue all the process and generally perform the duties of the clerk of a court as prescribed by law for a county clerk insofar as the same may be applicable. The municipal court clerk shall keep the records of the municipal courts of record, issue process, and generally perform the duties that a clerk of a county court at law exercising criminal jurisdiction performs for that court. In addition, the municipal court clerk shall maintain an index of all court judgments in the same manner as county clerks are required by law to prepare for criminal cases arising in county courts. The city manager may appoint deputy municipal court clerks, warrant officers, and other personnel as needed for the proper operation of the court. The municipal court clerk and other court personnel perform their duties under the direction and control of the presiding judge. 
(d)  Vacancy. A vacancy in the office of judge of the municipal court or municipal court clerk shall be filled for the unexpired term. 
(e)  Setting time of court sessions. The judge of the municipal court shall have power to set the time for court sessions as the docket may require. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1735,  1, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 58-67. - Failure to appear/violate promise to appear. 
(a)  Appearance required. That any person summoned or ordered to appear in the municipal court to face and answer a charge brought against that person by the city for violation of a state statute, city ordinance or other law or regulation shall appear in the municipal court at the date and time specified in the summons or order. For purposes of this article, the term "person" shall mean any corporation, partnership, joint venture, individual or any other entity recognized in law. 
(b)  Complaint. In the event a person summoned or ordered to appear in municipal court as outlined in subsection (a) fails to appear, the municipal court municipal court clerk shall be authorized and empowered to file a complaint in municipal court charging that person with failure to appear/violate promise to appear as summoned or ordered. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1735,  2, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 58-68. - Warrant fees. 
    The following fees are hereby be imposed and collected by the municipal court in the following instances: 
Defendant not convicted of misdemeanor. 
(1)  Whenever a warrant of arrest is issued and served and the defendant made the subject of the warrant is not convicted in the municipal court of the violation for which the arrest warrant was issued, a fee not to exceed the sum of $50.00 shall be imposed and collected by the city in the following instances. 
a.  When a person fails to appear in accordance with V.T.C.A., Penal Code  38.10, as amended, and with V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 543, subch. A; and 
b.  In all other instances where there has been filed a complaint providing that there has been a violation of law or ordinance which imposes criminal penalties for violations thereof, provided that written notice of the issuance of an arrest warrant and imposition of the warrant fee has first been given to the offender. 
(2)  The judge of the municipal court shall set the warrant fee authorized by this section in an amount not to exceed $50.00. 
(3)  The funds collected pursuant to this section shall be paid into the city treasury for the use and benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1735,  3, 11-17-09) 
Sec. 58-69. - Penalty for failure to appear violation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate this article, and any person found guilty of violating or failing to comply shall be fined, upon conviction, not more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. O-09-1735,  6, 11-17-09) 
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Discharging of firearms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to discharge any gun, pistol, or firearm of any kind. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  4(C)) 
State Law reference- Municipal regulatory authority concerning firearms and explosives, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code,  229.001; right to keep and bear arms in lawful defense of self and state, Tex. Const. Art. 1, Sec. 23; display or discharge of firearm, V.T.C.A., Penal Code,  42.001(7)-(9). 
Sec. 62-2. - Loitering. 
(a)  When unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in, on, or about any place, public or private, when such loitering is accompanied by activity or is under circumstances that afford probable cause for alarm or concern for the safety and well-being of persons or for the security of property in the surrounding area. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Any place, public or private, means and includes, but is not limited to, the following: All places commonly known as being distinctively public, such as public streets, public restrooms, sidewalks, parks, alleys, and buildings; all places privately owned but open to the public generally, such as shopping centers, transportation terminals, retail stores, movie theaters, amusement centers (outdoor or indoor), office buildings and restaurants; and all places distinctively private, such as homes or private residences and apartment houses. 
    Loiter means and includes walking about aimlessly without apparent purpose; lingering; hanging around; lagging behind; the idle spending of time; delaying; sauntering and moving slowly about, where such conduct is not due to physical defects or conditions. 
    Surrounding area means that area easily and immediately accessible to the person under observation. 
(c)  Suspicious activities. Without limitation, the following activities and circumstances may be considered in determining probable cause for alarm or concern: 
(1)  The flight of a person upon the appearance of a peace officer or any other person; 
(2)  Attempted concealment by a person upon the appearance of a peace officer or any other person; 
(3)  The systematic checking by a person of doors, windows or other means of access to buildings, houses, or vehicles; 
(4)  Repeated activity by a person, continuous or broken, which outwardly manifests no purpose, such as going from one place to another and back with no showing of use for such movement; 
(5)  Continuous presence by a person in close proximity to any building, house, vehicle, or any other property or to any other person, at any time, when the activity of such person manifests possible unlawful activity, such continuous presence being for an unreasonable period of time under the circumstances then existing; 
(6)  A change of direction by a person upon the appearance of a peace officer in order to avoid meeting or crossing paths with such officer; 
(7)  If on private property, the continued refusal of a person to leave such private property when requested to do so by the owner, manager, proprietor, or lessee of such property. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  4(D)) 
Secs. 62-3-62-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 62-26-62-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CURFEW[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-07-1624,  2, adopted July 10, 2007, amended art. II, div. 2, to read as herein set out. Formerly, said division pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Ord. No. O-94-958,  1, adopted Aug. 16, 1994; as amended by Ord. No. O-00-1235,  1, adopted Sept. 5, 2000. 

Sec. 62-36. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Curfew hours means: 
(1)  11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and 
(2)  12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Saturday or Sunday. 
    Emergency means any unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. Such term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    Guardian means: 
(1)  A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
(2)  A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court. 
    Minor means any person under 17 years of age. 
    Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
    Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  A natural parent, adoptive parent or stepparent of another person; or 
(2)  At least 18 years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
    Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways and common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings transport facilities and shops. 
    Remain means to: 
(1)  Linger or stay; or 
(2)  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(Ord. No. O-07-1624,  2, 7-10-07; Ord. No. O-10-1748,  2, 4-20-2010) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 62-37. - Offenses. 
(a)  A minor commits an offense if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(b)  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if such parent or guardian knowingly permits, or recklessly allows the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if knowingly or recklessly allowing a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(Ord. No. O-07-1624,  2, 7-10-07; Ord. No. O-10-1748,  2, 4-20-2010) 
Sec. 62-38. - Defenses to prosecution. 
(a)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under section 62-37 that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian; 
(2)  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian without any detour or stop; 
(3)  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
(5)  Involved in an emergency: 
(6)  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence; 
(7)  Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
(8)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly; or 
(9)  Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with V.T.C.A., Family Code Chapter 31. 
(Ord. No. O-07-1624,  2, 7-10-07; Ord. No. O-10-1748,  2, 4-20-2010) 
Sec. 62-39. - Enforcement. 
    Before taking any enforcement action under this division, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in a public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this division unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense under section 62-38 is present. 
(Ord. No. O-07-1624,  2, 7-10-07; Ord. No. O-10-1748,  2, 4-20-2010) 
Sec. 62-40. - Jurisdiction. 
    When required by V.T.C.A., Family Code 51.08, as amended, the municipal court shall waive original jurisdiction over a minor who violates subsection 62-37(a), and shall refer the minor to the county juvenile court. 
(Ord. No. O-07-1624,  2, 7-10-07; Ord. No. O-10-1748,  2, 4-20-2010) 
Sec. 62-41. - Review of juvenile curfew ordinance. 
(a)  Before the third anniversary of the date of adoption of a juvenile curfew ordinance by a general-law municipality or a home-rule municipality or an order of a county commissioners court, and every third year thereafter, the governing body of the general-law municipality or home-rule municipality or the commissioners court of the county shall: 
(1)  Review the ordinance or order's effects on the community and on problems the ordinance or order was intended to remedy; 
(2)  Conduct public hearings on the need to continue the ordinance or order; and 
(3)  Abolish, continue or modify the ordinance or order. 
(b)  Failure to act in accordance with subsections (a)(1)-(3) shall cause the ordinance to expire. 
(Ord. No. O-07-1624,  2, 7-10-07; Ord. No. O-10-1748,  2, 4-20-2010) 
Secs. 62-42-62-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Smoking tobacco, V.T.C.A., Penal Code  48.01. 

Sec. 62-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employee means a person who is employed in consideration of monetary compensation or profit. 
    Employer means a person, partnership, corporation, association or other entity that employs one or more persons. 
    Place of employment means an enclosed, indoor area under the control of an employer to which employees have access during the course of employment, and includes work areas, employee lounges, employee restrooms, conference rooms, and employee cafeterias. The term does not include a private residence. 
    Public meeting means a meeting open to the public and held in an enclosed area unless the meeting is held in a private residence. 
    Public place means an enclosed, indoor area that is used by the public or that serves as a workplace, and includes: 
(1)  All or part of a building used for state or local governmental purposes; 
(2)  A retail store, office, or other commercial establishment; 
(3)  A grocery store; 
(4)  A restaurant or cafeteria; 
(5)  A public primary or secondary school; 
(6)  A public institution of higher education; 
(7)  A school bus; 
(8)  A restroom; 
(9)  A health care facility; 
(10)  A theater, movie house, auditorium or arena; 
(11)  An elevator; 
(12)  A public means of mass transportation, including associated terminals; 
(13)  A courtroom; 
(14)  A jury waiting or deliberation room; 
(15)  A library; 
(16)  A child care nursery; 
(17)  A recreational facility; 
(18)  A place of employment; 
(19)  A place providing personal services; or 
(20)  A service line, cashier area, over-the-counter sales area, or common traffic area. 
    Smoke, smokes or smoking means: 
(1)  Carrying or holding a lighted pipe, cigar or cigarette of any kind or any other lighted smoking equipment or device; 
(2)  A lighted pipe, cigar or cigarette of any kind or any other smoking equipment or device; or 
(3)  Emitting or exhaling the smoke of a pipe, cigar or cigarette of any kind or any other smoking equipment or device. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  6(A)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 62-62. - Offense. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person smokes at a public meeting or in a public place and the person is not in an area designated as a smoking area under section 62-63. 
(b)  It is an exception to the application of subsection (a) of this section that the person is smoking: 
(1)  In a situation in which the person is present at an event in which an entire room or hall is used for a private social function and seating arrangements are under the control of the sponsor of the function and not of the proprietor or person in charge of the place; 
(2)  As a participant in an authorized theatrical performance. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  6(B)) 
Sec. 62-63. - Designation of smoking areas. 
(a)  Except as provided by subsection (e) of this section, a proprietor or person in charge of a public place who desires to permit persons in the public place to smoke shall designate areas as smoking areas. If the public place is a governmental building, the governmental entity responsible for managing and maintaining the building may designate areas as smoking areas. 
(b)  The proprietor or person in charge of a public place is not required to make structural or physical modifications to accommodate the smoking area, but existing physical barriers and ventilation systems shall be used to minimize the effect of smoke in adjacent nonsmoking areas. 
(c)  Each employer who operates a place of employment shall develop, implement, and maintain a written smoking policy that accommodates the wishes of smoking and nonsmoking employees by designating smoking and nonsmoking areas. If a dispute arises, the preferences of nonsmokers shall be accommodated. This subsection does not prohibit an employer from designating a place of employment in its entirety as a nonsmoking area. 
(d)  The proprietor or person in charge of a restaurant that has a seating capacity of more than 25 persons shall designate a smoking area proportionate in size to the number of customers normally requesting a smoking area. This section does not prohibit a proprietor or person in charge from designating a restaurant in its entirety as a nonsmoking area. 
(e)  Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, a smoking area may not be designated in: 
(1)  An elevator; 
(2)  A school bus; 
(3)  A public means of mass transportation; 
(4)  A restroom; 
(5)  A service line, cashier area, over-the-counter sales area, or common traffic area; or 
(6)  A place in which smoking is prohibited by the fire marshal of the state or a political subdivision or by other law, ordinance or rule. 
(f)  Subsection (e) of this section does not apply to a service line, cashier area, over-the-counter sales area, or common traffic area in a sports or entertainment facility with a capacity of more than 5,000. 
(g)  No place other than a bar or a retail store that primarily sells tobacco may be designated as a smoking area in its entirety. If a bar or tobacco store is designated as a smoking area in its entirety, that fact shall be posted conspicuously at all entrances to the premises. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  6(C)) 
Sec. 62-64. - Signs. 
(a)  A proprietor or person in charge of a public place shall place signs visible at each entrance to the premises to notify persons entering the premises that smoking is prohibited or that smoking is prohibited except in areas designated as smoking areas. 
(b)  A proprietor or person in charge of a public place shall post in a conspicuous place in any area designated as a smoking area signs stating that smoking is permitted in the area. The proprietor or person in charge may post signs in the premises stating "no smoking" or "no smoking except in designated areas," as appropriate. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  6(D)) 
Sec. 62-65. - Proprietor's duties to prevent smoking. 
    A proprietor or person in charge of a public place shall make a reasonable effort to prevent smoking by: 
(1)  Designating any areas where smoking will be permitted as required by this section; 
(2)  Posting signs as required by this section; and 
(3)  Asking smokers to refrain from smoking in all other areas on request of a client, patron, or employee suffering discomfort from the smoke. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  6(E)) 
Sec. 62-66. - Facilities to extinguish smoking materials. 
    All public conveyances and public places shall be equipped with facilities for the extinguishment of smoking materials. Facilities for extinguishment of smoking materials that are located in areas of public places other than designated smoking areas shall be accompanied by clearly visible signs stating "no smoking." 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  6(F)) 
Sec. 62-67. - Employer's written smoking policy. 
    Each employer required to adopt a written smoking policy under this article shall adopt the policy not later than 90 days after the date on which the business begins to operate. 
(Code 1980, ch. 7,  6(G)) 
Chapter 66 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Parks generally,  2.03; borrowing,  9.07; legal effect of master plan,  11.04. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; nuisances,  42-26 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to operate and maintain parks, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code,  331.001; park to be open for public use under rules prescribed by local governing authority, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code,  331.007; home-rule municipality has exclusive control over public grounds, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code,  282.001; municipal authority concerning public waters within corporate limits, V.T.C.A., Parks & Wildlife Code,  31.092. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Parks and recreation master plan. 
    The Parks and Recreation Master Plan, dated April, 1990, prepared by Schrickel, Rollins and Associates, Inc., is hereby adopted and designated as the parks and recreation master plan for the city. 
(Ord. No. O-90-788,  1, 9-4-90) 
Sec. 66-2. - Parks and recreation advisory board. 
(a)  Established; appointments; chairman; meetings; filling of vacancies; quorum; removal of members; records; compensation of members. There shall be established a parks and recreation advisory board which shall consist of eight citizens of the City of Colleyville. Members of the board shall be appointed by the council for a term of two years. Four members of the parks and recreation board shall be appointed each odd numbered year and four members shall be appointed each even numbered year. The board shall elect a chair for its membership and shall meet when action is required by the board. The chair of the board shall be a non-voting member except in the case of a tie. Vacancies shall be filled by the council for the remainder of the term. A quorum shall consist of five members. Members of the board may be removed by a majority of the council after public hearing and for cause set forth in writing. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings which shall be of public record. The board shall serve without compensation. 
    The board shall also consist of one non-voting liaison member from each of the Colleyville youth sport associations who shall be recommended by the association and appointed by the city council for a one-year term. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities. The duties and responsibilities of the parks and recreation advisory board shall be as follows: 
(1)  Act in an advisory capacity to the city council and the parks and recreation director in all matters, including finances, pertaining to parks and recreation and coordinate with other governmental agencies, civic groups and all citizens of Colleyville in advancement of sound parks and recreation planning and programming. 
(2)  Adopt a set of bylaws and recommend policies and procedures for the proper administration of the parks and recreation advisory board. 
(3)  Recommend policies on parks and recreation services to the city council. 
(4)  Recommend any and all usage of the Parkland Dedication Fund and Voluntary Park Fund to city council for consideration. 
(5)  Recommend the adoption of standards for recreational areas, facilities, programs and their financial support. 
(6)  Have periodic inventories made of existing services and survey of services needed and interpret the needs of the public to the city council and to the parks and recreation director. 
(7)  Recommend for acquisition by the city council certain lands and buildings deemed necessary for the use of the city parks and recreation programs. 
(8)  Submit recommendation for the improvement and expansion of the parks and recreation facilities, equipment and programs. 
(9)  The parks and recreation advisory board has the right to establish standing committees and other such committees as from time to time may be deemed necessary. 
(c)  Bylaws approved. The bylaws submitted by the parks and recreation advisory board are hereby approved. 
(Code 1980, ch. 1,  14(C); Ord. No. O-04-1446,  1, 2, 3-2-04; Ord. No. O-15-1970,  2, 9-15-15) 
Editor's note- The approved bylaws of the parks and recreation advisory board are on file in the office of the city secretary. 
Secs. 66-3-66-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC PARKS 

Sec. 66-26. - Trespassing; restricted areas and activities. 
(a)  Operation of motor vehicles. No person shall operate any vehicle which is propelled by a motor, including all types and forms of gasoline, electrical, or hydrocarbon fueled motors, upon any area within a public park except those areas specifically designed for vehicular use, such as streets and driveways. This prohibition shall not apply to motor vehicles actually engaged in delivery, vending or maintenance. 
(b)  Hours of operation. Public parks within the city shall be closed between 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. with the exception of Colleyville Nature Center which shall be closed from 30 minutes after sunset until 30 minutes prior to sunrise. The city manager is authorized to erect such physical barriers as shall be necessary to prevent entry. Special permission may be granted by the parks and recreation department for organized activities or special events which last past closing time in which case any park containing the permitted activities shall remain open until the activity shall cease, at which time the park shall be closed. Organizations may request a special use permit from the parks and recreation department for the purpose of hosting organized programs after hours. 
(c)  Loitering in restrooms. No person shall linger or loiter in or about a restroom in a public park. 
(d)  Prohibition on entering bodies of water. No person shall swim, wade, or otherwise enter in or upon any pool, tank, lake, creek or other body of water, other than a swimming pool, located within a public park. 
(e)  Restricted areas. No person shall disregard, fail to observe, or otherwise violate any prohibition or direction contained upon any sign in a public park erected by the city. 
(f)  Riding of animals. No person shall ride or drive any horse or other animal within a public park except along and upon paths designated for the use of such animals. 
(g)  Prohibition on erecting structures. 
(1)  No person shall place or erect any structure, sign, bulletin board, post, pole or advertising device of any kind in a public park. 
(2)  No person shall attach to any tree, shrub, fence, railing, post or structure within any public park, any sign, bulletin board or other advertising device of any kind. 
(3)  The prohibitions contained in subsections (g)(1) and (g)(2) of this section shall not be applicable to persons acting pursuant to and with the written authorization of the city manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. O-93-906,  1(A), 6-15-93; Ord. No. O-94-973,  1, 12-6-94) 
Sec. 66-27. - Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
    No person shall possess or consume any alcoholic beverages, including, without limitation, liquor, wine, or beer, within a public park, unless written permission has been given for such consumption by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-93-906,  1(B), 6-15-93) 
Sec. 66-28. - Damaging public property or animals. 
(a)  No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate, or deface any structure, monument, statue, vase, fountain, wall, fence, railing, vehicle, bench or other property located in any public park. 
(b)  No person shall cut, break, deface or in any way injure the trees, shrubs, plants, grass or turf within any public park. 
(c)  No person shall catch, injure, kill, strike or attempt to strike with any object or weapon any animal or bird within any public park. 
(Ord. No. O-93-906,  1(C), 6-15-93) 
Sec. 66-29. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  Golf. No person shall strike or hit a golfball or golfball-like device in a public park. 
(b)  Glass containers. No person shall possess a container made from glass in a public park. 
(c)  Projectile devices. No person shall possess, fire or discharge a device capable of propelling a projectile, including, without limitation, any firearm, airgun or pistol, bow and arrow, crossbow or slingshot, in a public park. 
(Ord. No. O-93-906,  1(D), 6-15-93) 
Sec. 66-30. - Limitations on sales. 
(a)  No person shall sell any food or other merchandise in a public park. 
(b)  No person shall charge admission or a fee for any purpose within a public park. 
(c)  The prohibitions contained in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply to persons acting pursuant to and with the written authorization of the city manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. O-93-906,  1(E), 6-15-93) 
Sec. 66-31. - Organized athletic and sporting events. 
(a)  The use of public parks for organized sporting or athletic events shall be conducted only in accordance with rules established from time to time by the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  No person shall disregard or act in contravention of any direction of the city manager or his designee concerning the use, occupancy, or other matter concerning the conduct of any organized sporting or athletic event within a public park. 
(Ord. No. O-93-906,  1(F), 6-15-93) 
Secs. 66-32-66-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC ATHLETIC AND RECREATIONAL FACILITIES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, adopted Nov. 19, 2002, amended art. III in its entirety. Formerly, said article pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Ord. No. O-98-1108,  1, adopted Sept. 1, 1998; as amended. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-51. - Definitions. 
    City cosponsored league play shall mean an athletic event, which is authorized, organized or scheduled with the assistance of the parks and recreation department by a non-profit organization. 
    City sponsored league shall mean an athletic event which is authorized, organized or scheduled in whole or in part by the parks and recreation department. 
    Closed field shall mean a playing field or a game field that has been closed for any use due to inclement weather or maintenance requirements of the parks and recreation department. 
    Director shall mean the director of the parks and recreation department. 
    Game field shall mean a field that has been designated by the parks and recreation department to be used solely for the purpose of conducting league play or tournament play for city sponsored or city cosponsored league play athletic events. This would include the city sponsored soccer, baseball and softball associations. Game fields are located at the Pleasant Run Soccer Complex and the Colleyville City Park. 
    Practice field shall mean a field that has been designated by the parks and recreation department to be used solely for the purpose of conducting practices or non-league play for city sponsored, city cosponsored league practice athletic events and public reservations. This would include the city cosponsored soccer, baseball and softball associations. Practice fields are located at Reagan Park and Pleasant Run practice site. 
    Park shall mean a park, playground or any other area in the city, owned or used by the city, devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Vehicle shall mean any wheeled conveyance, whether motor powered, animal-drawn or self-propelled. The term shall include any trailer of any size, kind or description. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  1, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  1, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Secs. 66-52-66-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FACILITY PROCEDURES AND GUIDELINES 

Sec. 66-61. - Tennis court regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use the tennis courts in the city for any purpose other than playing tennis. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to play tennis on any tennis court while wearing any footwear other than tennis shoes. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a skateboard or skates on the tennis courts. 
(d)  The tennis courts are available on a first-come first-serve basis. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-62. - Same-Reservations. 
(a)  The courts will open for play at 6:00 a.m. All games must be completed by 10:00 p.m., park closing time. 
(b)  Courts may be reserved through the parks and recreation department. Time slots for reservations are available in one and one-half hour increments as seasonal conditions permit. The schedule shall be determined and approved by the parks and recreation director or designated representative. 
(c)  Reservations must include the name of the individual or team, address and phone number as set forth in this policy. 
(d)  Residents may make reservations beginning the Monday proceeding the next scheduling week (Sunday through Saturday). Non-residents may make reservations commencing on Friday proceeding the next scheduling week (Sunday through Saturday). 
(e)  Any person or team found to be violating the terms of this section shall be denied access to the tennis courts for the remainder of the season. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-63. - Rental of park pavilions and refunds. 
(a)  The parks and recreation director shall designate a person or person(s) to inspect all premises after usage. All deposits will be held until after pavilion use, and returned to the customer unless damage or vandalism has occurred. At this time, a refund will be processed for the deposit. 
(b)  City related functions shall have first priority on the pavilions and shall use the pavilions without charge. 
(c)  All other groups who reserve the pavilion for personal use, except those specified in the following section, shall pay a fee as determined by the parks and recreation department. 
(d)  All residents and non-residents who reserve the facility for business, commercial or professional gatherings may apply for the use of said pavilion during daytime hours between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. The applicant may not make any charges, nor solicit for money of any kind or character from any person for his use of the pavilion. A liability insurance policy naming the city as an additional insured shall be purchased by all business, commercial or professional renters. Coverage amounts must meet those specified by the city manager or his designee. 
(e)  A request for a reservation must be made in person at the parks and recreation department during regular business hours (8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m.). Reservations will be accepted from adults only (18 years or older). Reservations may be made no earlier than 60 days in advance. 
(f)  A permit shall be issued by the parks department stating the time, date, fee and amount of deposit and any other pertinent information as determined by the city. 
(g)  Refunds on any pavilion or park rentals unless otherwise specified, must be requested no later than three working days after scheduled use, through the parks and recreation department director or designated representative. Refunds will only be considered in cases of uncontrollable events, i.e., severe weather, family emergency, etc., and must be approved by the parks and recreation director. Rescheduling of allotted time is preferred and can be used up to one year from the time of original date. 
(h)  All cancellations must be made no later than three days prior to reservation date to obtain a refund. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-64. - Park pavilion policies and guidelines. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages are prohibited, as per ordinance. 
(b)  Music may be played only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., unless otherwise approved by the parks and recreation department or as permitted under the city's noise and nuisance ordinances. 
(c)  Vehicles will be restricted to designated parking areas only, except for police, fire emergency or maintenance vehicles from departments. Also, the use of "bounce houses" or "moon walks" is not allowed on park property. 
(d)  Responsibility for damages to and or maintenance of facilities growing out of usage beyond normal and usual wear will be assumed by the individual, group or organization. All paper and waste shall be deposited in proper receptacles. 
(e)  All special permits must be obtained in person and such individual must sign such permit indicating that he/she agrees to the terms of the deposit restriction and applicable city ordinances. 
(f)  Decorations should not be attached to the pavilion that would tend to deface the structure including, but not limited to, staples, tacks, crepe paper, or any material that will stain. Approval shall be obtained from the parks and recreation department for any special decorations. 
(g)  Any open flames, candles (other than birthday cake candles), torches, etc. shall not be used in the pavilion and use of any decoration or equipment that requires electricity must meet appropriate fire and electrical codes. 
(h)  The city manager or his designee shall determine the applicable charge or fee when an interpretation is needed, or the charge set by the parks and recreation department is disputed. 
(i)  Failure to adhere to parks and recreation department rules and regulations will result in suspension of reservation privileges. 
(j)  All decisions concerning the applicable fee, the non-refund of any portion of the deposit, or the denial of the use of the pavilion may be appealed to the city manager or his designee. 
(k)  The individual, group or organization will obey all rules and regulations, both written and verbal, and will not hold the city liable for any injury sustained while using the facility. 
(l)  The person, whose signature appears on the reservation, or their representative is fully responsible for all participants using the facilities under the jurisdiction for the parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-65. - Parks, practice and game fields reservations. 
(a)  City related functions shall have first priority in the city's parks and shall use these parks without charge. 
(b)  Commercial use of any and all park facilities for filming, photographing, etc. shall require a charge plus a damage and clean-up deposit. 
(c)  The use of picnic areas and play equipment (other than pavilion renters) shall be on a first-come, first-serve basis. No reservations are allowed. 
(d)  Any group not sponsored by the city and desiring to use a park as a gathering place or for an event or function of any kind shall be subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  The organizer or representatives of the group desiring use of the park for an event or function shall file an application for a special permit with the parks and recreation department at least 30 days prior to the proposed date of the event or function. The application will be on a form provided by the parks and recreation department and shall include the following information: 
a.  Name, address and telephone number of the person or persons responsible for the event or function; 
b.  A description of the event and its proposed date and hours of duration; 
c.  Estimated number of people who will be in attendance; 
d.  The park and park area being requested for use; 
e.  The nature and number of vehicles, which will be used to transport people in attendance to and from the event; 
f.  A description of any voice or musical amplification equipment to be used; and 
g.  Any other information that may be required by the city in order to establish additional requirements for the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(e)  Within three days of the time the application has been filed with the parks and recreation department, the assistant city manager will be notified of the event or function and will be provided copies of the application for the purposes stated above and for the purpose of assessing the demand placed upon services by the event and the impact upon the area surrounding the park. 
(f)  In addition to the requirements set forth in this section, the group shall comply with any and all other applicable laws, statutes, ordinances, resolutions and rules governing use of the parks. These requirements include, but are not limited to, the payment of any fees or deposits, which may be required for the use of a public park by this article. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, adopted September 1, 2009, changed the title of section 66-65 from "Parks and game fields reservations" to "Parks, practice and game field reservations." The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 66-66. - Playing fields. 
(a)  Ballfields: Practice fields. 
(1)  Regulations. 
a.  During regular and post season play, all practice fields are reserved for the exclusive use of the youth sports associations, except for Sunday. 
b.  The city also uses G-CISD facilities for baseball and softball practice fields. 
c.  The city does charge a reservation fee for the practice baseball fields and softball fields at Reagan Park. 
d.  The city does not charge a fee for open space areas at park facilities that have a multi-use backstop such as Kimzey Park, McPherson Park and Senior Center Open Space. 
(2)  Fees and refunds. 
a.  The fee for each practice field for residents and youth sports associations, outside of regular and post season play shall be $35.00 (without lights) and $50.00 (with lights) per session. The fee for each practice field for non-residents shall be $60.00 (without lights) and $100.00 (with lights). Each session shall be no longer than two hours in accordance with the reservation schedule maintained by the parks and recreation department. 
b.  If the fields are not reserved, they will be available on a first-come, first-serve basis during daylight hours. 
c.  Refunds are available due to inclement weather, provided however, that a request for a refund is submitted to the parks and recreation department, in writing, within one week of scheduled session. Failure to submit a timely request for a refund forfeits the refund. Rescheduling in lieu of a refund is permitted based upon availability of time slots. 
(b)  Ballfields: Game fields. 
(1)  Regulations. 
a.  No person shall use the game fields in City Park for any purpose other than playing softball or baseball. 
b.  During regular and post season play, all game fields are reserved for the exclusive use of the youth sports associations, except for Sunday. 
(2)  Fees and refunds. 
a.  During regular and post season play, the youth sports associations pay a maintenance fee for use of the game fields. 
b.  The fee for each game field for residents and youth sports associations, outside of the regular and post season play, shall be $50.00 (without lights) and $80.00 (with lights) per session. The fee for each game field for non-residents shall be $100.00 (without lights) and $180.00 (with lights). Each session shall be no longer than two hours in accordance with the reservation schedule maintained by the parks and recreation department. 
c.  Commercial or organized teams or teams playing games other than those scheduled by the city's youth sports associations, shall be required to pay a fee, as established by the parks and recreation department. Field reservations are required for such teams. 
d.  Refunds are available due to inclement weather, provided however, that a request for a refund is submitted to the parks and recreation department, in writing, within one week of scheduled session. Failure to submit a timely request for refund forfeits the refund. Rescheduling in lieu of a refund is permitted based upon availability of time slots. 
e.  A request for a waiver of the use of the ball fields: Game fields must be submitted, in writing, to the parks and recreation department for consideration and approval of the city council. 
(3)  Reservations. 
a.  All fields are available by reservation only and only for the time slot reserved. Time slots for reservations are available in two-hour increments as seasonal conditions permit. The schedule shall be determined and approved by the parks and recreation director or representative. 
b.  Each person or team is limited to one time slot per week (Monday through Saturday) per calendar month. Reservations must include the name of the coach or assistant coach, address and phone number, as set forth in this article. No more than one person from a team may schedule a reservation. Reservations shall not conflict with scheduled youth sports association league play. 
c.  Youth sports associations and residents may make reservations one week (seven calendar days) prior to the succeeding month. Non-residents may make reservations commencing on the first business day of the month. 
d.  Any person or team found to be violating the terms of this policy shall be denied access to the fields for the remainder of the season. 
e.  The parks and recreation director or designated representative is authorized to designate any game field owned or leased by the city a closed field for maintenance or to protect the surface of the game field from damage. 
f.  It shall be unlawful to go upon a game field which has been designated as a closed field and has posted thereon a sign stating "Closed Field - Do Not Trespass Upon This Field - $1.00 - $500.00 Fine" unless the purpose for going upon a closed field is to maintain such field. 
(c)  Soccer fields: Practice fields. 
(1)  Fees and refunds. 
a.  The city does not charge a fee for practice soccer fields for youth sports associations and residents. 
b.  Commercial or organized teams or teams playing games other than those scheduled by the city's recreational sports associations, shall be required to pay a fee, as established by the parks and recreation department. Field reservations are required for such teams. 
(2)  Reservations. Practice fields are available on a first-come first-serve basis. Local sports associations and teams have priority. Any person or team found to be violating the terms of this policy shall be denied access to the practice fields for the remainder of the season. 
(d)  Soccer fields: Game fields. 
(1)  Fees and refunds. 
a.  The fee for each game field for youth sports associations and residents shall be $50.00 (without lights) and $100.00 (with lights) per session. The fee for each game field for non-residents shall be $125.00 (without lights) and $175.00 (with lights). Each session shall be no longer than two hours in accordance with the reservation schedule maintained by the parks and recreation department. 
b.  Commercial or organized teams, or teams playing games other than those scheduled by the city's recreational sports associations, shall be required to pay a fee, as established by the parks and recreation department. Field reservations are required for such teams. 
c.  A request for a waiver of the use of the soccer fields: Game fields must be submitted, in writing, to the parks and recreation department for consideration and approval of the city council. 
d.  Refunds are available due to inclement weather, provided however, that a request for a refund is submitted to the parks and recreation department, in writing, within one week of scheduled practice. Failure to submit a timely request for refund forfeits the refund. Rescheduling in lieu of a refund is permitted based upon availability of time slots. 
(2)  Reservations. 
a.  All fields are available by reservation only and for the time slot reserved. Time slots for reservations are available in two-hour increments, as seasonal conditions permit. The schedule shall be determined and approved by the parks and recreation director or representative. 
b.  Any scheduled game on the game fields or use of the game fields shall be played in uniform with licensed officials. 
c.  Each person or team is limited to one time slot per week (Sunday through Saturday) per calendar month. Reservations must include the name of the individual or the team and coach, address and phone number, as set forth in this article. No more than one person from a team may schedule a reservation. Reservations shall not conflict with scheduled league play. 
d.  Youth sports associations and residents may make reservations one week (seven calendar days) prior to the succeeding month. Non-residents may make reservations commencing on the first business day of the month. 
e.  Any person or team found to be violating the terms of this policy shall be denied access to the game fields for the remainder of the season. 
f.  The parks and recreation director or designated representative is authorized to designate any game field owned or leased by the city a closed field for purposes of maintenance or to protect the surface of the game field from damage. 
g.  It shall be unlawful to go upon a game field which has been designated as a closed field and has posted thereon a sign stating "Closed Field - Do Not Trespass Upon This Field - $1.00 to $500.00 Fine" unless the purpose for going upon a closed field is to maintain such field. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-67. - Other rental facilities, including but not limited to sand volleyball, in-line hockey courts and basketball courts. 
(a)  Fees. 
(1)  The city does not charge a fee for the use of the sand volleyball, horseshoes, foursquare, in-line hockey and basketball courts. 
(2)  No person shall use the tennis courts, the practice or game fields or any area of a public park to charge a fee for any purpose, including private lessons or clinics. 
(b)  Reservations. All courts are available for use on a first-come, first-serve basis. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-68. - Use of certain shoes prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to wear cleated shoes on the in-line hockey or basketball courts. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-69. - Concessions. 
    The city may have concession contract(s) granting particular vendors exclusivity. All concession vendors must obtain a health permit. Residents and non-residents may request use of a concession stand. Requests must be in writing and will be reviewed by the parks and recreation department director and the assistant city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-70. - Sports clinics. 
(a)  Any individual or group seeking use of a park or playing field to conduct a sports clinic shall reserve the park or playing field by completing the appropriate application forms in the parks and recreation department and pay a fee for the clinic to be held, as determined by the parks and recreation department. 
(b)  Scheduling of the clinics shall be determined and approved by the parks and recreation director or designated representative. Clinics shall not conflict with any scheduled league play. 
(c)  The applicant shall purchase a liability insurance policy naming the city as an additional insured, in an amount to be determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Sec. 66-71. - Enforcement. 
    The parks and recreation department shall have the primary responsibility for the enforcement of this policy and all codes and ordinances regulating the conduct and use of park and athletic facilities. The chief of police shall have secondary responsibility for such enforcement. 
(Ord. No. O-02-1372,  1, 11-19-02; Ord. No. O-04-1492,  2, 12-7-04; Ord. No. O-08-1687,  2, 7-15-08; Ord. No. O-09-1726,  1, 9-1-09) 
Chapter 70 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1]
