SECTION 4. - CHARGES FOR DEPOSITS FOR CONNECTIONS TO EXISTING MAINS AND LATERALS 

Sec. A. - Water service. 
    All applicants for water service will be required to make a meter deposit (payment security deposit) for each water service connection, such deposit to remain with the city throughout the term of the service contract. The amount of the deposit shall be determined as follows: 
1.  The deposit for all residential and commercial customers shall be $50.00 and the deposit for all customers using a city provided fire hydrant meter shall be $750.00. 
2.  For customers who have previously been eligible for discontinuance under preceding section 3.D, the deposit shall be determined by the utility billing supervisor to equal the multiple of $5.00 nearest the largest amount ever previously owed by that particular customer, but in no case [shall be] less than $30.00. 
    The deposit will be refunded, or in event a balance is due, applied against the final bill for services required upon termination of the contract. The city will not pay interest on meter deposit funds. 
    In locations where a complete service connection, including tap, service line, curb stop, meter and box were paid for or installed by a prior single customer, no charges are made other than the meter deposit (above) and the regular monthly service charges as set forth in section 3. 
    In locations where a complete service connection, including tap, service line, curb stop, meter and box were paid for or installed by a developer, the charge for the right to connect to the system shall be $100.00 plus the meter deposit set forth above and the regular monthly service charges as set forth in section 3. 
    For three-fourths inch and one inch connections (tap fees) the cost shall be $1,100.00. For one and one-half inch and two inch connections (tap fees) the cost shall be $1,400.00. For connections larger than two inches, the connection will be made by the applicant's utility contractor and inspected by the city. 
    Where applicable, there shall be added the cost of street repairs as follows: A minimum street cut of $100.00 shall be deposited at the time water service is requested and before service is started on installation of such connection. Should the final cost of the work exceed the amount of the deposit, a statement showing the amount of the excess will be immediately furnished to the person having made the deposit, and this amount will be due before water service is actually begun. Should the final cost be less than the amount of the deposit or estimate, a refund of overpayment will be immediately made to the person from whom the deposit was received. 
    Extension of the service piping from the city's meter and curb stop shall be accomplished by the customer at his/her expense; however, such installation shall be in accordance with the applicable ordinances of the city. 
    The use of a fire hydrant meter for a permanent or semi-permanent irrigation system shall be prohibited. 
    Any evidence of tampering or damage to a fire hydrant meter shall be documented at the time of reading and the meter shall be kept for repair. The customer shall be required to remit an additional security deposit of $750.00 for the use of another meter. 
    This deposit will be applied to the repair of the damaged meter. Upon completion of repair, the remaining monies will be applied to the account, if needed. If there is no outstanding balance on the account, the monies shall be remitted to the customer. 
(Ord. No. O-76-220, 2-17-76; Ord. No. O-87-649, 6-15-87; Ord. No. O-93-897,  3, 4-6-93; Ord. No. O-03-1406,  3, 6-17-03; Ord. No. O-14-1945,  6(Exh. B), 12-16-14) 
Sec. B. - Sewer service. 
    Applicants for sewer service who have also posted the meter deposit for water service to serve the same location are not required to post separate deposit for sewer service; however, if the applicant receives sewer service only, or for any other reason has not posted the water meter deposit, then they will be required to make a sewer service payment security deposit, in the amount of $10.00 for each such sewer service connection, which will remain on deposit with the city throughout the term of the service contract. The deposit will be refunded, or in the event a balance is due, applied against the final bill for services rendered, upon termination of the contract. The city will not pay interest on such deposit funds. 
Where the main or lateral sewer and service sewer has been installed by the developer within his development, the charge for the right to connect to the system shall be $100.00. 
(Ord. No. O-76-220, 2-17-76; Ord. No. O-87-649, 6-15-87) 
Where the city has extended lateral sewers or other sewer mains or said lateral sewers or mains are installed pursuant to section 5 hereof and the customer is not a participating individual, the charge for the right to connect to the system shall be computed as follows: 
The individual customer's front footage divided by the summation of all the individual customer's front footages receiving point of service by the sewer lateral extension project multiplied by the times the total cost [multiplied by the total cost] of the sewer lateral extension project including the cost of street repairs, other repairs and appurtenances. 
(Ord. No. O-86-618, 6-24-86) 
Where applicable there shall be added the cost of street repairs as follows: A minimum street cut [deposit] of $100.00 shall be deposited at the time sewer service is requested and before service is started on installation of such connection. Should the final cost of the work exceed the amount of the deposit, a statement showing the amount of the excess will be immediately furnished to the person having made the deposit, and this amount will be due before water service is actually begun. Should the final cost be less than the amount of the deposit or estimate, a refund of overpayment will be immediately made to the person from whom the deposit was received. 
Each single customer shall also be responsible for paying for cost and accomplishing the tapping of the sewer main or lateral and installation of the required tapping saddle, service sewer, and house sewer. All materials used and methods of construction shall be in full compliance with the latest specifications as adopted by the city and the applicable ordinances of the city. The person or persons actually performing the installation of the service sewer must be properly licensed plumbers in accordance with city requirement and shall obtain all permits, particularly including a permit from the city, prior to tapping the city's lateral sewer or other sewer, and no sewer service installation will be considered as acceptable for service unless and until the installation has been inspected and approved by a representative of the city prior to and after completion of the trench backfill. The permit of the city, as evidenced by a copy of the receipt for payment of the connection charge, shall be in possession of the person performing the installation of the service connection and shall be exhibited to the city's superintendent or inspector at his request. 
SECTION 5. - SYSTEM EXTENSIONS TO SERVE SINGLE CUSTOMERS OR GROUPS OF INDEPENDENT SINGLE CUSTOMERS 

Sec. A. - General. 
    This section shall apply only to single customers or groups of independent customers requiring system extensions to provide for connecting to the city's sewer and water systems, including subdivisions which have not previously been served by city sewers but excluding extensions for subdivisions which are covered in section 6. 
The city will extend its water distribution main a distance of not more than 50 feet per connection in any dedicated street or alley without additional cost to the customer above the standard connection charges covered in section 4. The city will extend lateral sewers or sewer mains only upon the payment of actual costs by the customer as provided in section 4. 
Should one or more single customers desire service which necessitates an extension of more than 50 feet per water connection or an extension of lateral sewers or sewer mains, such customers may advance the funding required with provision for future refunding as additional customers pay for connecting to the system by the procedure set forth under section 5.B following. 
The city does not commit to a policy of funding system extensions from surplus revenues, bond funds or other public sources of funds; however, in the event such funds become available, the city reserves the right to do so at its sole discretion. In such cases, priority of projects will be based upon the well-being of the public relative to health and sanitation, as well as the willingness of the customers involved to participate in the cost. 
Sec. B. - Method of procedure. 
    Where one or more single customer(s) desires to advance the funding necessary for the city to extend either its water or sewer systems, or both, to satisfy the requirements for points of service for their property, they shall make the request to the city secretary in writing, stating the lot and block number, name of subdivision and street address of the property to be served and the type or types of service required. Each request shall be signed by all property owners initially requesting service and their signatures shall be identified with the property they desire to be served. 
Upon receipt of such request, the city secretary will instruct the city's engineer(s) to prepare an estimate of the cost of the extension to satisfy the requested point of service, which shall include the actual cost of construction, together with the cost of the repair of all streets and other public utilities required by the construction. 
The estimated amount of construction as determined above for extending the distribution mains, lateral sewers or sewer mains for the requesting customer(s), plus the meter deposit prescribed for each of the initial customers requiring the extension as set forth in section 4, shall be deposited with the city by the individuals in proportions determined as hereinafter provided before construction is initiated by the city. The city shall pay for the engineering, administration, field surveys and other contingencies. 
Each single customer participating in the system extensions under this section of the city's policies shall execute a written agreement with the city setting forth in detail the location, extent, total and single customer cost of the extensions, and the name and address of the person to whom refunds are payable. 
After all required deposits are posted with the city, the applicants may stipulate that competitive bids be received from private contractors for performing the extensions, otherwise it will be left to the option of the city whether the work is to be let by competitive bids or performed by the city forces for the amount of the estimate. 
If bids are received on the work, the amounts of the deposit will be adjusted by additional collections or refunds to the actual contract cost plus the applicable meter deposits. Such adjustments shall be made upon the completion of the work and prior to connecting the customer for service. 
Sec. C. - Determination of proportions of extension charges assigned to respective individuals participating in extensions by groups. 
    Where groups of single customers join together to accomplish system extensions for service provided above, the proportion of the cost assigned to each participating customer shall be determined as follows: 
1.  The participating customer's cost shall be computed as follows: The individual customer's front footage divided by the summation of all the participating customers' front footages receiving point of service by the extension project multiplied times [multiplied by] the total cost of street repairs, other repairs and appurtenances. 
2.  In addition to the extension costs thus determined, the customers shall also pay the meter deposits provided for in section 4 and provide their own sewer service line and/or water connection to the meter. In the event an individual has prepaid to the city the sewer service connection fee pursuant to the policy established by the city heretofore, the city shall pay that individual's share of the participant's total extension cost. 
Sec. D. - Subsequent connections to extensions paid for by single customers or groups of single customers. 
    As intermediate customers between the last previous point of service and the extended point of service request and pay the standard connection charges plus extension charges as required to satisfy the intermediate customer's point of service requirement, refunds will be made to the customers who paid for the extension until the full amount advanced to the city for the extension has been repaid. Refunds shall be made to the initial customer within 30 days after the new customer connection charges have been paid to the city, and shall be divided among the initial participants in the same proportion as their participation in the extension. 
No refunds will be made five years after the construction of the extension project has been completed, nor shall refunds of less than $25.00 per participating customer be made. 
(Ord. No. O-86-618, 6-24-86) 
Sec. E. - Alternate extension procedure available to permit the extension of sanitary sewer main(s) to serve existing residences. 
    The city may extend sanitary sewers to service new areas previously not served when the city determines that such extension is in the best interest of the public and the city. 
1.  Conditional requirements. The city may require as a condition the following: 
a.  A petition signed and submitted by 60 percent of the property owners requesting sewer service; and/or 
b.  Acceptable binding commitments and/or deposit(s) of funds sufficient to pay for 60 percent of the extension costs (as estimated by the city's consulting engineer) before authorization of the extension. 
2.  Access charges. Access fees will be charged as follows: 
a.  Per tap available to all properties affected by the line extension and not otherwise served by sanitary sewer, limited to one tap per platted lot or tract. 
b.  Per tap access fee shall be computed by one of the following two methods: 
i.  Ten dollars per front foot (as defined in section 1 hereof for "front footage") and as may be revised hereafter by resolution necessary to address changes in construction costs. 
Provided further, that the front footage fee shall not be less than $1,000.00 nor more than $2,000.00. Additional taps for system access requested after the original computation as determined herein shall be the same as would have been charged otherwise. 
ii.  Where lots are uniform in front footage and the equity of the individual case indicates that a single fee may be the most appropriate and efficient method of assessment, the city council may act to adopt a per tap access fee based on an equal distribution of cost to be assessed to property owners for the extension project. 
The formula per tap access fee shall be the number of "front footage(s)" times $10.00 divided by the number of lots or tracts abutting the sewer line. 
No. of front footage(s)  $10.00 
Total no. of lots/tracts    =  Per tap 
access fee  
iii.  Where the per tap access fee computed under part (i) hereof would exceed $1,500.00, the city council may in lieu of charging [the] access fee provided for in part (i) hereof, establish a fee of $1,500.00, regardless of the additional cost necessary to serve the property in question. 
(Ord. No. O-94-946,  1, 5-3-94) 
c.  Subsequent additional taps within the line extension limits shall be charged the same access fees as apply to those initially receiving sewer service as a result of a sewer extension. 
3.  Payment Method. Customers shall be required to pay their per tap access fee, in full, prior to connecting the customer's service line to the city sewer main unless otherwise allowed as provided for herein. 
Customers unable to pay in full prior to accessing the city's sewer main may be allowed to pay out their access charge when: 
a.  An application for such payment method is completed and submitted on forms provided and approved by the city manager or his designee; 
b.  An interest charge of 91/2 percent per annum shall be charged for the payment period required; 
c.  Maximum payment period offered shall be 60 months; and 
d.  The city reserves the option under such approved time payment method to bill with utility bills, by separate statement, or with authorized bank drafts executed by the sewer customers. 
Provided, further, that the city manager is authorized to waive and/or revise payment methods in case of financial hardship when adequate verification of need is provided. 
(Ord. No. O-89-721, 7-25-89) 
SECTION 6. - SYSTEM EXTENSIONS TO SERVE SUBDIVISION DEVELOPMENTS 

Sec. A. - Basic policy and scope of charges. 
    The developer shall pay all costs attributable to the installation of water and sewerage facilities as needed to fulfill the basic criteria requirements of the city for service to his subdivision. Such costs generally include (but [are] not limited to) the following: 
1.  For easements, rights-of-way and sites, the total actual cost of acquisition unless the city council approves city participation as specifically provided in the developer-city agreement because of common usefulness for other functions of the city. 
2.  For engineering design and construction contract administration: 
a.  When city participation does not exceed $5,000.00: The total actual cost. 
b.  When city participation exceeds $5,000.00: The developer shall pay his proportional share of the cost. 
3.  When city participation does not exceed $5,000.00: For city review of construction plans, an amount equal to two percent of the construction cost or $500.00, whichever is greater. 
4.  For construction of facilities, the total actual cost unless the city council approves city participation for oversizing as specifically provided in the developer-city agreement. 
5.  For city inspection and acceptance fees, an amount equal to three percent of the construction cost. 
6.  For construction layout, cut sheets and for making field adjustments: 
a.  When city participation does not exceed $5,000.00: The total actual cost. 
b.  When city participation exceeds $5,000.00: The developer shall pay his proportional share of the cost. 
7.  Any fees, licenses or other mandatory costs assessed by others not within control of city shall be fully paid by developer. 
All subdivision extensions shall be covered by a written and executed agreement of form prepared or approved by the city's legal counsel which defines the scope and details of the proposed extension and particularly contains the developer's agreement to abide by all regulations of the city and to deliver to the city clear and unencumbered title to all the proposed improvements at the time of acceptance by the city, which must be prior to commencing service. 
The city shall participate in the cost of subdivision extensions only where and to the extent that oversized facilities in addition to the subdivision needs are required for the proper overall benefit of the system and when city funds for such oversizing are available. Such oversizing needs shall be determined by the city's engineer(s) with concurrence of the superintendent, and shall be authorized and included in the developer-city agreement only by approval of the city council. 
In all cases when the city's participation in the cost of facilities is more than $5,000.00, the city's engineer(s) will provide engineering design and construction contract administration, construction layout, cut sheets and make any required field adjustments. The developer shall deposit with the city his share of such engineering cost attributable to his proportional share of the construction cost as particularly detailed in the developer-city agreement. 
When the city participates in the cost of constructing the project by oversizing facilities, or other participation, the contract for construction shall be executed between the city and the contractor only after compliance with all Charter and statutory requirements for advertising and receiving competitive bids. When the city does not participate in the construction costs of the project, the developer may negotiate the unit prices and completion time with the contractor(s) of his choice, or, by mutual agreement of the developer and the city, sealed bids may be received. In either event, the contract shall be executed between the city and the contractor and in compliance with section 7 following. 
Refunds to the developer shall be made only on applicable situations involving connections to off-site facilities (approach mains) or boundary facilities, and then only when provisions for such refunds are specifically provided for in the city-developer contract executed prior to construction of the extensions. 
Sec. B. - Methods of procedure. 
    Preliminary action is first initiated by the developer receiving and acknowledging receipt of a copy of the city's policies and procedures. Developer then has his engineer prepare and submit to the director of public works a preliminary layout of proposed water and sewer extensions superimposed on an approved preliminary plat signed by the city, along with his tentative estimate of costs for the overall development for the first section if incremental development is proposed. The developer also submits the city's review fee of two percent based upon the tentative cost estimate, or $500.00, whichever is greater. 
After review by the fire chief, the director of public works forwards the material to the city's engineer(s) for review. City's engineer(s) review the proposed preliminary layout and returns to the city with comments and recommendations concerning acceptability, needed oversizing and cost estimates for the oversizing. 
Developer will not proceed beyond the preliminary planning stage for any portion of the project for which he proposes to request city participation and, in no event, will the city participate more than $5,000.00 in any portion of the project that is not designed by the city's engineer(s) and submitted for competitive bids in accordance with all city Charter and statutory requirements. 
Action toward the filing and improving of all or a portion of development covered by preliminary action as per above is initiated by the developer as follows: 
1.  When city participation in the cost of the project does not exceed $5,000.00. The city furnishes the developer with three blank forms of the standard city-developer agreement. Developer's engineer shall prepare and submit to the city complete construction plans, specifications and other necessary contract documents along with estimates of developer's cost and two blue line prints of the final plat showing approval signature for the City of Colleyville. Such documents shall be submitted to the city's engineer(s) for review and after they have been fully completed and are acceptable and approved by the city council, the city shall return them to developer with notice of approval in exchange for the executed city-developer agreement and the remaining three percent of the city's total fee of five percent based upon the final engineer's estimate of the construction cost. 
If contract is to be let for bid, the developer's engineer prepares and furnishes to the city a notice to bidders to be properly published with bids to be addressed to the city manager and received at the Colleyville city hall. 
After selection of the contractor has been accomplished by bids or negotiation as per above, the actual construction shall be accomplished as follows: 
If bids are received, developer's engineer receives and recommends award to city manager. If contract is negotiated, developer advises who is contractor and furnishes bid amounts. City manager or director of public works notifies developer to have documents executed and returned to city. After receipt of executed documents, city manager issues work order. 
After the work order is issued, the developer's engineer provides the construction layout, staking and prepares cut sheets for all sewers. A copy of all cut sheets shall be furnished to the director or inspector and the contractor. 
The inspector shall inspect the work and review the partial and final pay estimates to the contractor as prepared by the developer's engineer. After pay estimates have been agreed upon by the inspector and the contractor, they shall be transmitted to the director of public works for checking. 
The director of public works shall check all pay estimates and, after they are in order, shall transmit them to the city manager with recommendation for payment or corrections as noted. 
After final completion of the work to the satisfaction of the inspector and director of public works, the city manager shall issue a statement of acceptance of the facilities for ownership and operation by the city to the developer. 
2.  When there is to be more than $5,000.00 city participation in the project. The city furnishes the developer with three blank forms of the standard city-developer agreement. After developer-city agreement has been executed and the proper fees have been deposited with the city, the city instructs the city's engineer(s) to proceed with preparation of construction plans and documents and the advertising and receiving of bids. 
After selection of the contractor has been accomplished by bids, the actual construction shall be accomplished as follows: 
The city's engineer(s) shall furnish to the city secretary a tabulation of all bids. 
After deposit or other approved financing is arranged for the developer's share of the cost and developer has furnished volume and page where plat is filed of record, the city secretary advises the city's engineer(s) with instructions to have documents executed and issue the work order. 
City's engineer(s) then has documents executed and furnishes copies of the documents and work order to city secretary, developer, contractor and surety. 
After distribution of documents, developer shall deposit with city secretary three percent layout and administration, plus three percent inspection and acceptance fees based upon developer's proportional share of the construction cost. 
Work order is then issued by the city's engineer(s), who also provides the construction layout staking and prepares cut sheets. A copy of all cut sheets shall be furnished to the city's superintendent and the contractor. 
The city's director of public works or inspector shall inspect the work and prepare or check the partial and final pay estimates to the contractor. 
After pay estimates have been agreed upon by the director of public works, inspector and the contractor, they shall be transmitted to the city's engineer(s) for checking. 
The city's engineer(s) shall check all pay estimates and, after they are in order, shall transmit them to the city secretary with recommendation for payment. 
After final completion of the work to the satisfaction of the superintendent or inspector, he shall prepare a statement of acceptance of the facilities for ownership and operation by the city, which shall be received for comment by the city engineer(s) and forwarded to the city council for final action. 
Sec. C. - Evaluated prices. 
    When the city participates in the cost of facilities for oversizing or for any other reason, separate bid items shall be set up to reflect the cost to the city when such separate items can be feasibly determined. In the absence of such specific bid prices, the price shall be determined by using a current bid price or city engineer(s) estimated price. 
Sec. D. - Developer payments. 
    When any extension or improvement to the water and/or sewerage system is to be installed under contract between the city and a contractor, the cost of which is to be paid wholly or partially by a developer, the contractor shall not be authorized to commence work until after the city has received the full amount due from the developer, either in cash to be placed in escrow or by irrevocable commercial letter of credit from a bank or other lending agency acceptable to the city, and conditions of such letter to be included in the city's developer agreement and of form approved by the city attorney. 
Sec. E. - Charges and/or refunds on off-site and boundary facilities. 
    When any customer, whether an individual, residential [or] commercial builder, developer or any other person, desires a service connection direct to an existing water or sewer line that was previously installed as a boundary or off-site facility of an extension serving another development or other individuals, the charges for each such connection to the line shall be assessed in accordance with the terms of the preceding section 4.A and 4.B. 
When a developer installs off-site or boundary facilities in which the city does not participate in the cost in any way, such developer shall become eligible for refunds from future connections to these facilities by fully identifying in the city-developer agreement the line location and extent of such boundary or off-site facilities. Such refunds shall be made only from the connection charges as they are paid by customers not within the platted area of development covered by the agreement. The determination of such refunds shall be made by the same formula as set up in preceding section 5.D. 
When portions of an increment of a development necessitates facilities that are boundary or off-site relative to the initial increment, but later furnished direct service to subsequent increments, then such later connections may be made without payment of additional connection charges by the same developer or his legal heirs, assigns, successors, or executors; however, if the subsequent development is by others, then connection charges will be assessed and refunds to the original developer will be made if so provided in his city-developer agreement. 
(Ord. No. O-77-252, 6-21-77) 
Editor's note- See also requirements for utilities in subdivisions in the city's land development code, on file in the office of the city secretary. 
SECTION 7. - STANDARD REQUIREMENTS AND CRITERIA OF DESIGN FOR SYSTEM EXTENSIONS 

Sec. A. - Contract documents. 
    All contract documents for extensions of improvements to the city's water or sewerage facilities shall be prepared under the supervision and bear the seal of a registered professional engineer, who shall be licensed by the State of Texas. Such documents shall consist of the following: 
1.  Notice to contractors. 
2.  Wage rates. 
3.  Proposal. 
4.  Contract (standard form of agreement). 
5.  Bid bond (unless contract is negotiated by developer). 
6.  Performance bond, comply with applicable statutes of the State of Texas. 
7.  Payment bond, comply with applicable statutes of the State of Texas. 
8.  Maintenance bond (ten percent of total contract for two years). 
9.  Certificate of insurance. 
10.  General conditions of the agreement. 
11.  Special conditions. 
12.  Project technical specifications. 
13.  City standard technical specifications. 
14.  Plans. 
Sec. B. - Sizing of water and sewer facilities. 
    All new water and/or sewerage facilities are to be sized to adequately serve the needs of the city based upon the land use plan in effect at the time of construction. Any proposed development which is in contrast to the land use plan and thus causes existing water and/or sewer facilities to be inadequate, will pay all cost necessary to provide for the increased capacity required by the revised land use. 
Sec. C. - Water system design and construction standards. 
    The criteria of design and the materials and workmanship used in extensions or improvements to the city's water system shall conform to the master plan(s) and standards adopted by the City of Colleyville, as well as to all applicable rules and regulations of the state natural resources conservation commission. Situations requiring discretionary determination not covered by specific regulation shall be resolved by recommendation of city's engineer and action by the city council with consideration for applicable standards of the American Water Works Association, state department of insurance and other recognized authorities. 
Nonrising stem gate valves with slip or screw type iron cover boxes and other control devices shall be installed throughout the system for proper control, maintenance and operation of the system. 
    Fire hydrants shall be "Mueller Centurion" (or approved equal) with safety flange. Operating nut to be a 11/2-inch pentagon that turns counterclockwise to open. Pumper nozzle shall be 41/2-inch and after installation, fitted with a five-inch "Hydra-Storz" adapter with a self closing butterfly valve assembly. Hydrant shall be coated with "Kem-Luster" vermilion red or equivalent coating. Bonnet and caps [are] to be coated with "Scotchlite" silver reflective paint (or approved equal) after installation. Installation shall be according to the standards of the American Water Works Association and have a nominal three feet of cover over the connecting main. Each hydrant [is] to be provided with a gate valve with anchor couplings to main and hydrant. 
    Water distribution mains, not serving fire hydrants shall not be smaller than four inch, and when four-inch mains are installed, they shall not be used to serve more than 20 standard three-fourths inch single connection or ten double one-inch service connections, and no four-inch distribution mains shall exceed 1,000 feet in length between direct connections to larger mains. 
    Fire hydrant locations shall be according to the current fire code. Water distribution mains shall not be smaller than six inches and this size used only in residential areas. A six-inch dead-end main is not considered satisfactory for supplying fire hydrants. A minimum size of eight inches shall be used in commercial and high density residential areas. 
All supply mains and distribution mains installed within a developer's platted and filed area of development must extend to the borders of his development as required for future extension of the city's system, regardless of whether or not such extensions are required for service within the area of development. 
Sec. D. - Sewerage system design and construction standards. 
    The criteria of design and the materials and workmanship used in the extension of [or] improvement of the city's sewerage system shall conform to the master plan(s) and standards adopted by the City of Colleyville, as well as to all applicable design criteria for sewerage system of the Texas state department of health. Situations requiring discretionary determinations not covered by a specific regulation shall be resolved by recommendation of the city's engineer(s) and action by the city council with consideration for applicable standards of the recognized societies and authorities. 
Approach sewers shall be designed with consideration for servicing the full drainage area subject to collection by the system, subject to modification by the city, if necessitated by the projected rate of development and the financial feasibility of the proposed extension. Lateral sewers shall be designed to serve the planned area of development with provision for extension where possible into adjacent undeveloped areas. 
All lateral sewers or sewer mains installed within a developer's platted and filed area of development must extend to the borders of his development as required for future extensions of the collecting system regardless of whether or not such extensions are required for service within the development. 
The construction of sewage lift or pumping stations or separate treatment facilities will not be permitted unless the cost of constructing such lift stations or separate facilities is at least 30 percent less than the costs of constructing an adequate outfall or approach sewer to serve the area. 
Gravity flow sewer laterals and mains 12 inches and smaller shall be extra strength vitrified clay pipe, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe or acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS) composite sewer pipe. 
Gravity flow sewer mains larger than 12 inches shall be of the type selected for the particular job involved. 
Service lines (house services, etc.) shall be extra strength vitrified clay pipe, cast iron soil pipe or PVC sewer pipe. 
(Ord. No. O-76-220, 2-17-76) 
State Law reference- Creation and structure of state department of insurance, V.A.T.S., Insurance Code art. 1.01A. 
SECTION 8. - FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-16-1986,  4, adopted September 6, 2016, repealed the former Sec. 8,  A-G, and enacted a new Sec. 8 as set out herein. The former Sec. 8 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-89-741, adopted September 19, 1989; and Ord. No. O-11-1788,  4, adopted January 18, 2011. 

Sec. A. - Guidelines adopted. 
    As a means of ensuring the financial integrity of the utility enterprise fund, the City Council hereby adopts the following as financial management guidelines: 
1.  Gross revenues of the utility enterprise fund shall be sufficient during each and every fiscal year period to pay all maintenance and operating expenses, debt service on all outstanding indebtedness payable by the fund, depreciation expense, and other nonoperating expenses. Retained earnings and working capital balances available from prior years shall not be used as a means of satisfying this requirement. 
2.  Net income before depreciation and other nonoperating expenses shall [be] equal to at least 1.2 times the average annual debt service requirement on all outstanding indebtedness secured by a pledge of utility fund revenues. 
3.  The working capital balance in the utility enterprise fund at the end of each fiscal year shall be equal to at least 90 days of operation. 
4.  The City shall develop and maintain accurate cash flow projections to ensure that sufficient funds are available at all times to pay current obligations of the utility enterprise fund, and to ensure that available cash is invested to the fullest extent possible. 
5.  All assumptions and projections concerning utility fund revenues and expenses shall be reviewed on at least an annual basis to ensure the adequacy of existing water and sewer rates. 
6.  Utility fund revenues and expenses shall be formally monitored on at least a quarterly basis to ensure that budget estimates are still valid. 
(Ord. No. O-16-1986,  4, 9-6-2016) 
Sec. B. - Separate account for delinquent penalties. 
    A separate revenue account is established in the water and sewer utility enterprise fund to account for penalties on delinquent utility bills. 
(Ord. No. O-16-1986,  4, 9-6-2016) 
Sec. C. - Pass through rate increase. 
    The City Council may by resolution increase water and sewer rates to pass through direct rate increases, originated by the Trinity River Authority, on a per 1,000 gallons basis for water delivery or sewer treatment charges on all water and sewer gallons billed and those gallons of usage included in the water and sewer minimum bill. 
(Ord. No. O-16-1986,  4, 9-6-2016)

Land Development Code City of Colleyville, Texas
Chapter 1  General Provisions P a g e 1 - 1
Chapter 1
General Provisions
Rev. 08/21/2018
Section 1.1 Title
This document shall be known and may be cited as the Land Development Code of the City of Colleyville, Texas.
Section 1.2 Applicability
The provisions of this Land Development Code shall apply to all lots, parcels of land, rights-of-way, buildings and structures located within the Corporate Limits of the City of Colleyville.
Section 1.3 Authorization for Adoption of This Land Development Code
The regulations contained in the various chapters of this Land Development Code have been adopted upon approval of an ordinance, after public hearing, by the City Council of the City of Colleyville in accordance with the authority described within each chapter and the following:
1. Chapter 51  General Powers of Municipalities of the Texas Local Government Code, which authorizes a municipality to adopt ordinances, rules, or police regulations that are for the good government, peace, or the trade and commerce of the municipality; and.
2. The Home Rule Charter of the City of Colleyville, which authorizes the City Council to exercise all powers granted to municipalities by the Constitution or the laws of the State of Texas.
Section 1.4 Purpose of the Land Development Code
The purpose of this Land Development Code is to promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the community and to:
1. combine zoning, subdivision and other regulations into a single document that can be used for development of property and public facilities in Colleyville, Texas;
2. establish reasonable standards of design and procedures for subdivisions in order to further the orderly layout and use of land, and to ensure proper legal descriptions of subdivided land;
3. provide that the cost of improvements which primarily benefit the tract of land being developed be borne by the owners or developers of the tract and that the cost of improvements which primarily benefit the entire community be borne by the community as a whole; and
4. avoid overlapping, conflicting or inconsistent regulations found in land use control systems consisting of separate zoning, subdivision, and other ordinances.
Section 1.5 Purpose of This Chapter
The purpose of this Chapter is to:
1. establish rules, regulations and procedures for the administration of this Land Development Code and to establish the process for amending this Code;
Land Development Code City of Colleyville, Texas
Chapter 1  General Provisions P a g e 1 - 2
2. establish regulations which describe the process for considering waivers, variances and appeals regarding this Land Development Code; and
3. establish specific boards and commissions responsible for considering requests for a waiver or variance from a regulation or to hear an appeal of a decision of an Administrative Official authorized to enforce and administer this Land Development Code.
Section 1.6 Administration and Enforcement
The provisions of the Land Development Code shall be administered, interpreted and enforced by the City Manager, his designee, or by the administrator designated within this Code.
Section 1.7 Fees
The schedule of fees and charges associated with application filing, processing, plan review, or any other fee required by provisions of this Land Development Code, shall be established by the City Council. Furthermore, until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid in full, no action shall be taken on any application or appeal authorized by this Land Development Code. Fees required by this Land Development Code shall not be refundable, except where a specific provision provides for refunding.
Section 1.8 Compliance Required
All land, buildings, structures or appurtenances thereon located within the City which are hereafter occupied, used, erected, altered or converted shall be used, placed and erected in conformance with the regulations prescribed herein. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of these regulations shall be construed to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, convenience, comfort, morals and general welfare. Land used in meeting the requirements of this Land Development Code with respect to a particular use or building shall not be used to meet the requirements for any other use or building. No approval, authorization to proceed, or issuance of any certificate or permit shall be construed as an approval of a violation of the provisions of this document or of other ordinances of the City of Colleyville. Certificates presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this document or of other ordinances of the jurisdiction shall be void.
Section 1.9 Certificate of Occupancy Required
1.9.A CERTIFICATE REQUIRED PRIOR TO OCCUPANCY
No building, or portion thereof, or parcel of land shall be occupied or used until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the City. Furthermore, no non-residential building, or portion thereof, or parcel of land shall change in use or occupancy until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the City. A current certificate of occupancy is required on all land, buildings, or portions thereof except non-habitable accessory buildings. Failure to comply with this provision may result in the issuance of a citation and/or constitute basis for denial of or disconnection from City utilities or to require a franchised utility company to do likewise.
1.9.B CONNECTION TO UTILITIES
No connection to the City utility systems shall be allowed unless and until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the City Inspector. However, temporary connection of utilities for a specified duration may be authorized by the City Inspector for the purpose of clean up, construction or other such purposes.
Land Development Code City of Colleyville, Texas
Chapter 1  General Provisions P a g e 1 - 3
1.9.C RECORDS
The Building Inspection Office shall maintain a record of all buildings or parcels of land for which a Certificate of Occupancy has been issued.
1.9.D CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY APPLICATION
Application for a certificate of occupancy shall be made to the Building Inspection Office. No application for a certificate of occupancy shall be approved which does not, at a minimum, contain the following information: business name, business address, business phone number, type of proposed use, business owner, business owner's address, business owner's phone number and emergency phone number, applicant's driver's license number, applicant's date of birth, and applicant's signature.
1.9.E DISPLAY AND STATUS OF CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY
1. All non-residential occupancies shall display a certificate of occupancy on the site and in a conspicuous place.
2. The holder of a certificate of occupancy for a non-residential occupancy is required to notify the Building Inspection Office of any change of address, name changes, or other pertinent information listed on the certificate of occupancy application.
Section 1.10 Project Under Construction at Time of Code Adoption
Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the plans, construction or designated use of a building actually under construction within the city on the effective date of this document and which entire building shall be completed within one (1) year from the effective date of the document or which building shall be maintained under continuous construction even though not completed within one (1) year. Nothing herein contained shall require any change in plan, construction or designated use of a building for which a building permit has been heretofore issued while such permit is valid and provided the building shall have been started within 180 days of the date of issuance of the permit and which entire building shall be maintained under continuous construction even though not completed within one (1) year.
Section 1.11 Compliance Required for Building Permits & Utility Services
No building or structure may be erected, constructed or installed on any lot, tract or parcel of land and public utilities shall not be extended or connected to a building or structure unless the lot, tract or parcel of land is in compliance with the provisions and requirements of this Land Development Code and all applicable Building Permits and authorizations to proceed are first obtained.
Section 1.12 Waivers and Appeals - Generally
Any person seeking approval of a development as required by this Land Development Code may request a waiver of or a variance from a requirement contained in this Code, or appeal a decision of an Administrative Official by submitting a request using the procedures described in this Chapter. Due to the unique arrangement and statutory organization of this Land Development Code, provisions for waivers, variances and appeals of administrative decisions vary from chapter to chapter. The following table shows the approval authority for waiver, variance and appeal requests for the specific chapters of this Land Development Code.
